column26: he could not have had any strong objection to keeping you. You don't complain that he treated you brutally?''Anyhow
column27: ' Mr. Westlake continued
column28: 'I have decided to write to Major Ruston
column29: and tell him all the circumstances
column30: offering to do anything on your behalf which he wishes; then I shall take a train to Castlemore the first thing to-morrow morning and have a chat with Mr. Turton.''That is what I feel compelled to do
column31: ' he said
column32: 'and what I hope will happen is this. I hope that Mr. Turton will take you back and promise me to treat you well until there's time to get an answer from Madras. If that answer is unfavourable
column33: though it is not in the least likely to be
column34: I shall see Mr. Turton again. In any case
column35: we must have no more wanderings. There has been enough of that. Supposing that Major Ruston cannot do anything
column36: and Mr. Turton declines to keep you
column37: we must make the best of a bad job. No doubt I can find you employment in a firm with which I am connected
column38: and you ought to have sense enough to see that this is the very best thing to be done in the circumstances.''Understand
column39: ' he said
column40: 'I don't intend to lose sight of you again. At the worst
column41: you will have to work for your living; but
column42: in the meantime
column43: ' he added
column44: 'I am going to put you on your honour. You must give me your word not to attempt to leave the house alone until my return.'Of course I gave my word
column45: but I felt that my last hope had gone. All that I had done
column46: all that I had passed through
column47: had been to no purpose. I might as well--far better--have stayed at Castlemore
column48: since there seemed little doubt that I should be taken back to Ascot House to-morrow. I could imagine Augustus's triumphant snigger
column49: and all the humiliation of the return.

column1: 'I should not be surprised
column2: ' said Jacintha
column3: later in the afternoon
column4: 'if Mr. Turton refused to take you back
column5: and if he does
column6: ' she exclaimed
column7: 'Father is going to see whether Mr. Windlesham will have you until he hears from Major Ruston.'I went to bed early that night
column8: and slept perfectly until one of the maids knocked at my door the next morning. But when--as soon as we had finished breakfast--Mr. Westlake was driven away from the door in a hansom
column9: I felt that my own departure might be only a matter of a few hours. During the morning Mrs. Westlake took me out for a drive with Jacintha
column10: but try as I might it was impossible to show them a cheerful face
column11: and while I understood that Mr. Westlake was doing what he considered the best for me
column12: it seemed difficult not to regard him as an enemy. That afternoon I sat in the dining-room
column13: unable to attempt to make my escape because of the promise which I had given Mr. Westlake
column14: yet feeling that there were few things I would not endure rather than eat humble pie and go back to Mr. Turton.But
column15: for some reason
column16: I placed very little confidence in Aunt Marion
column17: who
column18: I felt certain
column19: had entirely washed her hands of me before her marriage. Presently Jacintha suggested that we should go to another room where there was a chess-table
column20: but it was impossible to fix my thoughts on the game
column21: and she checkmated me twice in ten minutes.'Perhaps he wouldn't have me back after all
column22: ' I answered
column23: and then I felt suddenly cold from head to foot
column24: for the voice of Mr. Westlake's companion sounded remarkably like one which I had never hoped to hear again. Unable to restrain myself
column25: I ran out to the hall
column26: and there stood Captain Knowlton giving his hat and stick to the butler.'Ah
column27: Jack!' he said
column28: with one of his casual nods; and he took my hand as if he had parted with me yesterday
column29: and had been expected back as a matter of course to-day. But I began to laugh and cry by turns
column30: clinging to his hand as if I were fully determined never to let him go again. Our commonest bird is the sparrow
column31: that plucky
column32: impudent
column33: little creature which hops about in our gardens and yards
column34: and twitters upon our roofs all day long. It seems rather difficult at first to understand why it should be so much more common than other birds. It is not large or strong
column35: or swift on the wing
column36: and it seems to have none of those advantages which would help it to defend itself against enemies. It is not handsome
column37: and it is not a sweet songster
column38: so that man is not disposed to give it much protection. He is often prompted to destroy it
column39: because of the injury which it does to his gardens and his crops.But in spite of all its difficulties
column40: the sparrow thrives
column41: and brings up a numerous family
column42: because it has less fear of man than other birds have. It frequents the haunts of men
column43: while other birds are scared away from them. It requires some courage to brave the noise and tumult of a town
column44: but the sparrow possesses this courage
column45: and is rewarded accordingly. As other birds are too timid to trust themselves to a life among houses and streets
column46: the sparrow needs no protection from them.Ordinary as the sparrow is in almost every respect
column47: we cannot but admire its courage and its wariness. It is surrounded by many dangers
column48: and it is not only surprising how it braves them
column49: but also how watchfully it looks out for them
column50: and how cleverly it learns to avoid them. We all know how it watches the cats and the dogs
column51: and even a man with a gun
column52: and seeks a place of safety at the first sign of danger.One of the newspapers recently gave a very striking instance of a sparrow's confidence and coolness. A passenger who was waiting for a train in one of the Underground Railway stations observed a sparrow hopping upon the rails in search of crumbs. A train came into the station from the direction in which the passenger wished to travel
column53: and he had leisure to watch the sparrow. It allowed the engine to come within a few feet of it
column54: and then
column55: instead of flying away
column56: it quickly hopped off the rail upon which it stood
column57: and hopped into the space between the rails. There it lay until the train puffed out of the station
column58: when it jumped upon the rails again
column59: and resumed its search for crumbs. Presently another train entered the station
column60: and the sparrow was seen to repeat its previous action
column61: and to take refuge once more between the wheels of the train.

column1: The squirrel in the woods is as full of frolic and play as a kitten. One would think that it had not a care or anxiety of any kind to break in upon its play. And yet it has food to find
column2: a family to bring up
column3: a winter nest to make
column4: and several stores of food to lay up ready for those occasional days when it wakes up from its long winter's sleep.This winter sleep of the squirrel
column5: and some other animals
column6: is something very strange
column7: which we do not thoroughly understand. With the first touch of winter's cold
column8: they curl themselves up
column9: and fall into a sleep which lasts until the return of spring. This sleep
column10: or hibernation as it is properly called
column11: is a very useful habit for the animals which are subject to it
column12: because it enables them to live on at a time when their food is very often scarce. During this sleep their bodies scarcely waste away at all
column13: and a few good meals
column14: when they wake
column15: soon put them right; whereas
column16: if they were always running about
column17: they would be almost incessantly hungry
column18: and would probably die of starvation during the winter.Some animals remain torpid throughout the winter
column19: while others wake up occasionally
column20: and enjoy a day's life every now and then in the midst of their long sleep. The common squirrel is one of the latter. Whenever there is a warm
column21: mild day in winter
column22: it wakes up
column23: feeling very hungry
column24: and turns out of its nest for a run. If it trusted to chance for a meal
column25: it would have to return to its nest hungry. But during the autumn it has gathered large quantities of hazel-nuts
column26: acorns
column27: beech-nuts
column28: and fir-cones
column29: and has stored them away in various holes near its nest. When
column30: therefore
column31: it has enjoyed one of its winter runs
column32: it visits one of these store-houses
column33: makes a hearty meal
column34: and then returns to its nest to sleep for a few more days
column35: or a few more weeks
column36: until another warm day comes round.The squirrel selects for his storehouses various holes in the trunk of the tree near his nest
column37: which are often the deserted nests of some wood-pecker. Indeed
column38: he is not always content to wait until the wood-pecker deserts her nest
column39: especially as he relishes the taste of an egg. A writer in the _Standard_ describes how he saw a wood-pecker turned out of her house to make room for an impudent squirrel. The squirrel
column40: descending backwards down a tree-trunk
column41: suddenly found his hind legs in a hole. Probably he felt something sharp pecking at them
column42: for he drew them out quickly
column43: and rapidly climbed to a branch immediately above. A moment later a wood-pecker flew out of the hole. The squirrel watched her out of sight
column44: and then returned to the nest
column45: and helped himself to an egg or two
column46: which he carried up to his perch
column47: and ate.When these were disposed of
column48: he descended once more to the wood-pecker's nest and waited for the return of the bird. The moment she appeared at the entrance to her nest
column49: the squirrel flew at her like an angry cat. The startled wood-pecker fled in fear
column50: and the squirrel came forth triumphantly and went away for a short time. Whilst he was away the wood-pecker came again and looked into her nest. Something
column51: however
column52: probably a broken egg
column53: displeased her
column54: and she flew away again. Shortly afterwards her mate looked into the nest
column55: but he
column56: too
column57: was dissatisfied
column58: and flew away. Many times they returned to the nest
column59: but always with the same result. At length they seemed to make up their minds that they could never make their home in that nest again
column60: and they flew away to another part of the wood. The squirrel promptly took possession of the deserted nest
column61: and when autumn came he turned it into a store-house for nuts. Slates are not so much used in our schools as they were years ago
column62: exercise-books being cheaper now. Still
column63: there are some schools where the children have slates
column64: and pocket-books are to be bought
column65: containing a slate tablet
column66: on which you can write notes
column67: and rub them out afterwards to make fresh ones. Slates upon the roofs of houses are objects familiar to us all. Probably few
column68: young or old
column69: who have to do with slates
column70: ever think what this substance is
column71: and where it has come from. Yet slate is one of the most wonderful things in this world of ours.

column1: Supposing the first question put to us was
column2: 'What is slate?' our answer would be
column3: 'It is simply a sort of dried mud.' If the second was
column4: 'What is its place amongst the rocks of our earth?' we should say
column5: 'Slate belongs to the Cambrian formation.' This is a big series of rocks
column6: sometimes eighteen thousand feet thick. It contains in the middle what geologists call _flags_ and _grits_
column7: but the larger part of it is slates. There is but one series of rocks more ancient than the Cambrian
column8: and that is the one called the Laurentian
column9: which is said not to be found in Britain.'Cambrian
column10: ' some might say: there is a reason for that name
column11: which of course is only another word for Welsh. Though
column12: in their first order
column13: these slaty rocks lie deep down
column14: they have been lifted high up
column15: and they show us some of the grandest scenery we have in this island. The hills and precipices of Wales
column16: and the hollows where the mountain streams flow
column17: tell of the shakings and twistings that the Cambrian rocks have gone through. Amongst them grow ferns and rare flowers
column18: while many a tourist draws in new strength as he mounts them. Sometimes
column19: high up
column20: the rains and winds have made the rocks so bare that even mosses cannot live upon them
column21: and in the clear sunlight the slates appear of various shades
column22: from pink to deep blue.One curious thing about slate is that the layers are often twisted or wrinkled. This has been caused
column23: partly at least
column24: by their being thrust up when half hardened
column25: so as to cause a sort of fold or crease. This was chiefly done by the still harder granite.It is wonderful to think of the succession of plants and animals that slate has had to do with; it was in existence when the coal forests were forming
column26: and it must have been trodden by the strange creatures of other strata
column27: which are now extinct
column28: but of which relics are dug up. Another remarkable fact is that the slate-beds have had wonderful ups and downs over and over again during the earth's changes--being at one time under a deep sea
column29: at another lifted to form hills
column30: as we frequently see them now.The man was not missed for some time
column31: and
column32: when search was made
column33: the poor fellow was found nearly frozen to death. Some one had thoughtlessly slammed the door of the refrigerator
column34: which could only be opened from the outside.Fortunately
column35: the head steward noticed that the key of the ice-room was missing
column36: and this led to the man's discovery. If he had not been found till the following day
column37: he would probably have been the first man to be frozen to death in one of the hottest parts of the world. With the return of Captain Knowlton the story seems to come to its natural end; but
column38: although he had heard from Mr. Westlake all about my own adventures
column39: there still remained
column40: of course
column41: a great deal to discuss.When he was presented to Mrs. Westlake
column42: she insisted that we should both dine in Grosvenor Gardens
column43: and as it was difficult to refuse anything to one who had shown me such kindness
column44: Captain Knowlton apologised for his travelling clothes and consented. Presently
column45: when we were all sitting down together
column46: Mrs. Westlake begged for Captain Knowlton's story. He leaned back in his arm-chair
column47: beginning in an easy
column48: conversational tone
column49: as if he were telling us about a walk from one part of London to another.'It was April when I left the Solent in the _Seagull_
column50: ' he said
column51: 'making for Gibraltar
column52: where I picked up two or three men of my old regiment
column53: and cruised for a week or two in the Mediterranean. Early in May I sailed for Madeira
column54: touched at the Canaries
column55: then steamed south
column56: crossed the line
column57: and in due course reached Capetown. There the man who was to have accompanied me for the whole trip found a telegram to the effect that his father lay seriously ill in Vienna
column58: so that I had to continue the voyage without him. A few days out from Capetown we got into very bad weather
column59: which grew worse and worse until
column60: in the middle of the roughest night I ever experienced
column61: we were run down by a huge liner
column62: which brutally went on her way
column63: leaving us to our fate. The skipper wanted to be the last to leave the _Seagull_
column64: but I sent him off with seven or eight of the crew
column65: and
column66: before the rest could get away
column67: the ship went down under us. I found myself in the water
column68: one moment lifted high on the crest of an enormous wave
column69: the next sunk in the trough. I gave myself up for lost
column70: when something was washed against my arm
column71: and seizing it
column72: to my great good fortune
column73: I found that it was one of our life-rafts
column74: which had served as a seat on the _Seagull's_ deck.

column1: 'The night was the blackest you can imagine; from the moment the ship foundered I saw nothing either of the boat's crew or of the men who had been left with me. For what seemed an endless time I clung to my raft
column2: and I imagine that the tide must have carried me some distance from the scene of the wreck. As the night wore on--it seemed as if it would never pass--I grew weaker and weaker
column3: but presently the sky became lighter
column4: and just as I was telling myself that I might as well let go of the raft and bring things to an end
column5: I saw a small schooner close by. After half an hour of terrible suspense
column6: I began to think she was bearing down upon me
column7: and
column8: with such strength as I had left
column9: I shouted. At last
column10: thank Heaven
column11: I succeeded in attracting attention; a line was thrown
column12: and after some little trouble
column13: more dead than alive
column14: I was hauled on board.'The schooner was a Spaniard bound for Valparaiso
column15: but she had lost two men--washed overboard in the storm--and been a good deal knocked about. In fact
column16: I began to think that my end had only been postponed for a few hours. She had sprung a leak
column17: the water seemed to be gaining
column18: and after a short rest I took my turn at the pumps with the crew. However
column19: we rode out the storm
column20: and then
column21: two or three days later
column22: we lay becalmed for three weeks. She was
column23: at the best
column24: the slowest craft I have ever seen
column25: and everything seemed to be dead against her. We were many miles out of our course
column26: the stock of provisions--such as it was--and of water ran short
column27: and although the captain seemed very little dissatisfied
column28: I grew more and more hopeless.'Naturally
column29: ' said Captain Knowlton
column30: with a glance in my direction
column31: 'I thought a good deal of Everard. I knew that there was no one but myself to provide for him
column32: and that in any case I should be given up for lost. Even if (as happily proved to be the case) our skipper succeeded in getting to land
column33: he would be certain to report all the crew that were not in his boat as drowned--as
column34: in fact
column35: they all were except myself. I fumed and fretted to reach land
column36: but that was all I could do
column37: and when at last we got to Valparaiso
column38: I lost no time in sending Mr. Windlesham a telegram.''Yes
column39: sir
column40: ' the Grimsby shopkeeper answered cheerfully
column41: suspecting that his young
column42: gentlemanly-looking customer required the things for a fancy-dress entertainment or theatricals. In two or three minutes he had produced for inspection a jersey
column43: thick trousers--commonly called 'fear-noughts'--heavy top-boots
column44: and a set of oilskins.'I will try them on
column45: ' the lad said
column46: and
column47: retiring behind a screen
column48: changed his clothes. Then he looked round for a glass
column49: anxious to satisfy himself that he had the appearance of a North Sea fisherman. The shopkeeper
column50: unasked
column51: assured him that he had
column52: and
column53: as there was no one else there who could be consulted
column54: the youth purchased the outfit.The clothes _were_ meant for use after all. Charlie Page--for that was the lad's name--was not going to a fancy-dress ball
column55: but had purchased his fisherman's outfit because
column56: on the following morning
column57: he was to begin work as a deck hand on board the steam trawler
column58: _Sparrow-hawk_.How it came about that he was bound for the Dogger Bank needs explanation. His father was a prosperous Lincolnshire man who had built up a large export business
column59: which was now about to be converted into a limited liability company. Mr. Page was to become managing director of the new company
column60: but
column61: unfortunately
column62: he could find no suitable position in the concern for his son Charlie. He determined
column63: therefore
column64: to purchase
column65: with a portion of the money which he would receive from the company
column66: a new business for his son.He had heard that there were three Grimsby steam trawlers for sale
column67: and entered into correspondence with the respective owners. The price which they asked for the trawlers was not high if they really earned what it was asserted they did
column68: but Mr. Page had a strong suspicion that the amount of their profits was exaggerated.

column1: 'Shall I go to Grimsby and discover the truth?' Charlie said to his father one evening rather suddenly. 'I might get a job on one of those three trawlers and keep a sharp look-out all the while I was aboard her. I could count the boxes of fish
column2: and get all the information that I could from the crew.'There was a great deal of discussion before Charlie's daring plan was finally adopted. Mr. Page was struck by his son's grit and keenness
column3: and knew
column4: moreover
column5: that the experience would do him good. In his own young days
column6: before he returned to Lincolnshire and settled down to business
column7: Mr. Page had spent three eventful years in South America
column8: and although he had had many decidedly unpleasant adventures
column9: he by no means regretted them. He was glad
column10: too
column11: to find that his son inherited some of his love of adventure
column12: especially as it was to be used
column13: in this case
column14: for a good
column15: sensible purpose. Charlie was only sixteen
column16: but he was big and strong for his age
column17: and the sea air and hard life would probably do him good physically as well as morally.Charlie thanked him heartily
column18: and an hour or two later started for Grimsby. He knew the town well
column19: and making his way to the docks
column20: had little difficulty in finding where the _Sparrow-hawk_ lay. She was coaling when he discovered her
column21: and knowing that all hands would be busy
column22: he sat down on the black scaffold-like dock and watched from a distance as truck after truck was tilted over
column23: sending its load of coal into the shoot
column24: down which it ran with a rattle on to the ship's deck. The trawler's men
column25: black as niggers
column26: shovelled the coal quickly into the hold. Fortunately the greater portion of the load had been taken aboard before Charlie arrived
column27: and after waiting for about half an hour
column28: he saw the last truck-load shot down. He knew then that in about an hour's time some of the _Sparrow-hawk's_ men would be coming ashore. He watched them with interest as
column29: having shovelled all the coal into the hold
column30: they turned the hose on the deck
column31: and with brooms and swabs worked hard to remove the coal-dust which coated everything. When this task was finished
column32: the men gathered around two buckets and washed themselves. They needed washing badly.The first two men who came ashore had friends waiting for them
column33: so that Charlie had no opportunity of speaking to them. The third man to come ashore had no one waiting for him. He was a short
column34: bow-legged little man
column35: with a goatee beard and a small brass ring in the lobe of each ear. Charlie spoke to him.The hotel at which Charlie had taken a room was close to the docks
column36: and
column37: therefore
column38: the manager and waiters were not horrified
column39: as they would have been at a London hotel
column40: at seeing a rough fisherman brought into the building.'Ah! I see your game
column41: sir. You have heard what a rough time we fellows have in the North Sea
column42: and you have come down here to get information
column43: and then put it in a London newspaper. But it's no good
column44: sir. There's no skipper in the North Sea who wouldn't guess what you were up to
column45: and make some excuse for not taking you aboard his ship. You must give up the idea
column46: sir.'

column1: 'That's a splendid idea
column2: sir
column3: ' he declared
column4: 'and I only wish you could get a job on the _Sparrow-hawk_
column5: for you would see enough on that trawler to make you write till you wore out your pen. The skipper is an old villain
column6: and that crafty too----'The bow-legged fisherman did not finish his speech
column7: but nodded his head
column8: and raised his hands in horror
column9: as if words were too weak to express the real character of the skipper. Naturally
column10: Charlie became more anxious than ever to make a trip on the _Sparrow-hawk_.'That would mean that I should have to shave nothing every morning
column11: just to keep up the deception. If I didn't
column12: the crew would wonder why my beard didn't grow. But
column13: joking apart
column14: I am very anxious to make a trip in the _Sparrow-hawk_
column15: and if you
column16: at the last moment
column17: will pretend that you are too ill to go aboard
column18: and will send me as a substitute
column19: I will pay you your wages
column20: and give you a present as well.' Though the English people
column21: on the whole
column22: disbelieved the tales they heard of the French balloonists
column23: they became very interested when a certain young Italian
column24: named Vincent Lunardi (Secretary to the Naples Ambassador)
column25: gave out that he was willing to build a balloon and make a voyage in it. Those devoted to science contributed willingly to the expenses
column26: and large crowds paid to be allowed to see the balloon while it was being made. When nearly complete
column27: it was exhibited in the Lyceum
column28: and the arrangements made with the proprietor of that building very nearly led to disaster. He proved to be a greedy
column29: dishonest man
column30: and when Lunardi wished to move the balloon to where the ascent was to be made
column31: he refused to let it go unless he was paid half of all Lunardi secured by the venture
column32: and a large share in any profits that might be made on future occasions. Here was a difficulty Lunardi had not expected
column33: and it came with many others equally unlooked for. When Lunardi first made the proposal
column34: he had got leave from the Governors of Chelsea Hospital to ascend from their spacious grounds; but
column35: while the balloon was being made
column36: a certain Frenchman had set up in opposition
column37: and announced that he would give a display immediately. This promise he failed to keep
column38: and the disappointed sightseers paid him back by breaking up his machinery. The idea of such a thing being repeated terrified the Governors of Chelsea Hospital
column39: and they requested Lunardi to go elsewhere. He had just got over this trouble by being promised the ground of the Honourable Artillery Company
column40: when the proprietor of the Lyceum refused to release the balloon. The Artillery Company
column41: thinking themselves the victims of a fraud
column42: ordered the apparatus
column43: which had been sent to them
column44: to to be thrown off the ground unless Lunardi found securities in five hundred pounds to cover any injuries their premises might suffer at the hands of the mob. But the proprietor of the Lyceum had overreached himself
column45: and when the matter was explained he was compelled to give up the balloon
column46: which was forthwith taken to the artillery grounds under a special guard.Two days later the scene of action was thronged by a noisy crowd
column47: and Lunardi has spoken of the dread he felt lest anything should happen to delay the ascent. While the balloon was being filled
column48: he viewed the assembly from the upper storey of the Artillery House. Windows
column49: roofs
column50: and scaffoldings were crammed
column51: while in the large square below
column52: the people were so closely packed that it 'looked like a pavement of human heads.' And they were by no means orderly
column53: for most had come with the idea that they were to be deceived. The arrival of the Prince of Wales
column54: however
column55: put them in a better humour
column56: and in less than two hours after the appointed time
column57: Vincent Lunardi carried out his promise. He would not risk a longer delay. Though the balloon was only two-thirds full of gas
column58: and he had to disappoint a friend who had arranged to sail with him
column59: he gave the signal and weighed anchor.The grumblings of the fickle crowd turned to roars of applause
column60: as the balloon rose slowly over the house-tops. The noisiest and the roughest there forgot the jests they had made at Lunardi's expense. And Vincent Lunardi forgot them
column61: too
column62: for his worry was over
column63: and his long labour rewarded.He had made his balloon without any valve at the top
column64: and in order to descend
column65: had fitted it with long oars
column66: shaped like lacrosse sticks. These he now began to work in order that the vast crowds
column67: who had not been near enough to see him embark
column68: might know that he was in the car. But scarcely had he placed his hands upon them
column69: when one of the oars snapped off
column70: and returned to the earth. It was instantly broken into fragments by the crowd
column71: the pieces being kept as relics by those who were fortunate enough to secure them.

column1: Over the common of North Mimms Lunardi again plied his oars
column2: and landed
column3: with the assistance of some country folk
column4: in a field called Etna. Here he released a cat which he had brought from London. It had felt the coldness of the upper air considerably. A dog and some pigeons had also accompanied him
column5: and with these he continued his journey
column6: finally landing at Ware. A stone erected on the spot tells
column7: to this day
column8: the story of his adventure.As regards his mention of the oars
column9: it has been pointed out that
column10: since Lunardi had to throw out ballast when rising the second time from Etna field
column11: it is hardly likely that his descent was due alone to the working of the oars. It must have been through loss of gas
column12: and he deceived himself in thinking otherwise.London was delighted at the news of his voyage. George III.
column13: who had broken off an important state conference to peep through his telescope at the wonderful balloon
column14: afterwards allowed the young Italian to kiss his hand at a brilliant leve. Military honours were bestowed upon him
column15: and with fewer obstacles in his way he now made fresh flights.But perhaps his greatest triumphs were in Spain
column16: the king of which country gave him a residence in the royal palace at Madrid. Here

column19: he made a grand ascent

column29: 'Have you any Chinese friends?' Chinese rice-paper is a thing which we frequently hear of
column30: but do not often see. It is very curious and pretty
column31: but far too frail for most of the uses to which we put our English paper; and
column32: for this reason
column33: it has no commercial value in European countries
column34: and is only brought away by travellers and traders as a curiosity.The rice-paper which I have seen was cut into small squares about three by two inches
column35: each of which had a beautiful coloured picture of a Chinese man or woman. The paper was very white and thin
column36: slightly rough
column37: like blotting-paper
column38: stiff and brittle. It was impossible to fold it
column39: as the least effort to bend the sheet broke it in two. The pictures upon these little sheets had evidently been painted by hand
column40: and were very beautiful and interesting. The surface of the paint was bright and clear
column41: and the paper was transparent enough to permit the picture to be seen from the back
column42: with all its colours and details only a little dimmed
column43: as if seen through a thin sheet of ground glass.Notwithstanding its name
column44: rice-paper has really nothing to do with rice. It is not made from rice
column45: nor even from the rice plant
column46: but from the pith of a kind of ivy
column47: the _Aralia papyrifera_
column48: which grows abundantly in the island of Formosa. This _Aralia_ is not much like our English ivy. It is
column49: in fact
column50: a small tree
column51: which may attain a height of twenty or thirty feet
column52: and is crowned with a number of large leaves
column53: shaped like those of the sycamore. It bears clusters of small
column54: pale yellow flowers
column55: which contrast beautifully with the dark green foliage. The stem is ringed with the marks of the fallen leaves
column56: very like the stems of the castor-oil plants which are often seen in pots in England.

column1: The stem of the rice-paper plant is hollow
column2: and filled with a pith which
column3: though it is rather broken in the centre
column4: is firm and compact outside. After the tree has reached a certain age
column5: the pith becomes less serviceable
column6: and so the tree is usually cut down when it is about twelve feet high
column7: before it has attained its full growth. The stem is cut into lengths of nine or twelve inches each
column8: and the pith is pushed out by inserting a stick at one end
column9: and hammering it through the core of the tree. The little rolls of pith obtained in this way are placed in hollow bamboos
column10: which permit them to swell a little
column11: but prevent them from curling up as they dry. When properly dried
column12: they are ready for the cutting
column13: which is the really skilful part of the making of rice-paper. The man who cuts up the pith has a long
column14: sharp knife
column15: which he places against the side of the roll of pith in such a way that it will take off a thin paring as he turns the roll round and round. It is like paring off the bark of a log by rolling it round against a sharp knife

column50: -- Sago is made from the pith of a tree-trunk. This tree--the sago-tree--is a kind of palm

column55: either by the sea or in little hollows by the hill-sides. It is thicker than the cocoanut palm

column19: and a portion of the bark is shaved away from the upper side of the trunk so as to lay the pith bare. A native takes a club with a sharp stone in the end of it and beats the sago-pith with it. By this means he breaks up the fibres and the pith into little chips
column20: taking care that they are kept within the trunk. From time to time these chips are loaded into one of the sheaths of the midribs
column21: and carried away to be cleaned. The beater continues to break up the pith until there is nothing left but the hollow tree-trunk.The sago is separated from the fibres in the pith by the aid of water. The natives take two sheaths of the sago-plant and make them into water-troughs. They set them up upon little frames
column22: one sheath a little higher than the other
column23: with one of its narrow ends projecting like a spout over the lower sheath. A kind of net-like bark or skin
column24: obtained from the cocoanut tree
column25: serves as a strainer or sieve
column26: and is stretched across the upper sheath or trough. They empty the broken pith into the trough above the strainer
column27: and pour water upon it. The soft part of the pith is a kind of starch
column28: which dissolves in the water
column29: and so flows through the sieve and down the spout into the lower trough
column30: but the fibres are held back by the sieve. In order to get all the sago-starch out of the pith
column31: the sago-maker kneads and squeezes the pith until nothing but fibre remains. This is waste
column32: and is thrown away. When the sago-laden water falls into the lower trough it rests awhile
column33: and the sago sinks into the bottom of the sheath as a soft reddish sediment
column34: while the clear water rises to the top
column35: and by and by trickles over the end of the sheath. When this trough is nearly full the sago-starch is taken out
column36: made into rolls
column37: and wrapped in the leaves of the tree.The sago thus prepared is known as raw sago
column38: and is used by the islanders without being further refined. They boil it in water
column39: and eat it with fruits and salt

When our grandfathers and grandmothers were young

column42: after being moistened
column43: is passed through a sieve into a shallow iron pot

column1: Grown-up insects seem to be very short of legs compared with many of their distant relatives. Thus, while no member of the insect tribe--when grown up--has more than six legs, the Centipede or the Millipede may, as their names imply, possess a far greater number--as many, indeed, as two hundred and forty-two! But there is one curious likeness between the legs of the insects and those of their relatives--the number of pairs of legs is always odd. The insect has three pairs; the centipede and millipede have a very variable number, ranging from fifteen to one hundred and twenty-one pairs!We have seen how wonderful the foot of the fly is, with its two sticky plates for smooth surfaces, and its two claws for rough ones. The Honey-bee has very similar feet, but the two plates are joined to form one! As in the fly, when climbing rough surfaces the flat plates are raised up, and the claws used instead; but when a smooth or slippery place has to be crossed, the claws are pulled backwards and the plates are brought down.The legs of insects vary much, according to the purpose for which they are used. Thus, the Gnats, which spend the greater part of their time on the wing, have long slender legs, suitable for breaking the shock of alighting. Whilst in other insects the legs are used for all kinds of work, such as seizing prey, carrying it, climbing, digging, and so on. When this is the case the legs are provided with spines, or bristles.In the Mole Cricket (fig. 1) the fore-legs are very strong, being short and broad, and ending in a broad comb-like plate, which is used for digging. They are very like the great digging paws of the mole.The exact way in which insects walk is not easy to describe, and much study has been given to this most puzzling subject. Many devices have been adopted to make the insect draw a map of its course. In one instance the legs of a slow-walking beetle were painted, and the insect was then made to walk upon a clean sheet of paper; the track made by each leg being distinguished by the use of a different colour.From this and other experiments it appears that there are always three legs in motion at the same time, or nearly so; meanwhile the remaining three legs support the body. First (as in fig. 2) the left fore-leg steps out, then the right middle-leg and the left hind-leg. Then the movement is taken up by the legs of the opposite side of the body, and so on.If the movement of the legs in the six-legged insects is difficult to find out, what shall we say when the centipede (fig. 3) and millipede come to be examined? These, though not insects, are nearly related to the insects, and since they are common in our gardens, must be referred to here. 'Happy till One day a toad, in fun, Said, "Pray which leg moves after which?" This raised her doubts to such a pitch She fell exhausted in the ditch, Not knowing how to run.'The last pair of legs in the centipede and millipede are never used for walking, and are generally much longer than the rest. In a South American species they are provided with delicate nerves, and are used as antenn or 'feelers,' so that the animal is armed with organs of touch at each end of the body! In one kind of millipede, in the male the last pair of legs has a sound-producing apparatus, consisting of a ridged plate, which, by being rubbed against a set of tiny, bead-like bodies set in the surface of the last shield covering the body, produces a peculiar noise.Centipedes and millipedes generally shun the light, and hide under stones and in crevices during the day. But there are some which love the sunlight. These kinds are remarkable for the great length and slenderness of the legs, which they part with readily when handled! Most of these long-legged species are brightly coloured with black and yellow stripes or spots. In their native haunts these creatures may be seen darting about after their prey in the sun, heedless of the notice they attract by reason of their pretty colours. Few birds or beasts would think of eating them, for these creatures have a providential instinct which tells them that the gaudily-coloured animals are generally very nasty to the taste!

column9: and carries them off to London. But single boaters have to take in their own fish to Grimsby
column10: and therefore they have to run in every few days
column11: or else the fish wouldn't be fresh.''I don't know. The skipper is a curious kind of fellow
column12: and he may refuse to let you go
column13: so that he may have the pleasure of bullying you. Why don't you pretend that you are ill? He would put you ashore very soon then.'Then the skipper turned his attention to prying into the pots and pans
column14: to see if he could discover anything which would give him an opportunity to find fault. To his evident annoyance he did not succeed in discovering anything
column15: for Charlie had done his work thoroughly
column16: and the cooking utensils looked much cleaner than when he entered on his duties.Ping Wang shook his head
column17: and the skipper immediately flung the contents of his mug full in the Chinaman's face. The tea was very hot
column18: and with a cry of pain Ping Wang ran at his tormentor. Stepping backwards quickly
column19: to avoid him

column21: and fell heavily on to the deck.The other men were already asleep. The ventilators were all closed
column22: and the foc's'le was so close and stuffy that Charlie thought
column23: at first

column31: with a view to hauling. 'We must not forget the gardener

column1: 'What is your pleasure

column24: than it did to jump in to the rescue of the boy in the Black Sea. The wonderful contrivances by which animals manage to do beautiful work without tools
column25: to walk without feet
column26: to fly without wings
column27: to talk without a voice
column28: and to make their wants known not only to each other but to their human friends
column29: without understanding or speaking human words
column30: would fill a large book. No creature boasts of a hand like our own; even that of the monkey
column31: though his fingers resemble man's
column32: has a thumb which is nearly useless. The American spider-monkeys prefer to use their long tails as hands
column33: plucking fruits with the tips and carrying them to their mouths. The elephant uses his nose as a hand (for his trunk is nothing else but a long nose)
column34: and with this makeshift hand he can pick up either a heavy cannon or a sixpence from the ground. The horse uses his tail as a hand to drive off flies which he cannot otherwise reach. On board ship a hen was once seen to use her neck as a hand. She and the other fowls used to quarrel over the laying-boxes
column35: and though the nests looked all alike to a human eye
column36: this hen coveted one special box
column37: and would lay nowhere else. One day her master took the china nest-egg out of the box and put it into another one
column38: to see what she would do. He watched her through the chink of a door
column39: and saw her hunt till she found the egg
column40: curl her neck round it like a big finger
column41: lift it thus
column42: and carry it back to the old box
column43: where she sat on it in triumph.Stories of rats who have been seen to carry off eggs
column44: embracing them by their tails
column45: are common enough
column46: and everybody has watched animals of different kinds using their mouths to carry things from place to place. Not only lions
column47: tigers
column48: wolves
column49: and bears carry their young in this way
column50: but rabbits
column51: squirrels
column52: mice
column53: and many other creatures. The mother-whale tucks her little one under her huge fin
column54: using it as a hand and arm in one; in time of danger she carries him off thus at the risk of her own life from under the very harpoons of the whalers.All young animals have an instinct which prompts them to run to their parents for protection when frightened
column55: trusting not only in the older and wiser heads
column56: but in the faithful hearts which have never failed them. Though sheep
column57: cattle
column58: deer
column59: and such-like
column60: have no notion of using their jaws as hands
column61: or of lifting their little ones
column62: many of the young will use their limbs to cling to those who are stronger and swifter than themselves. The four-footed elders will perish rather than desert the youngsters
column63: and will
column64: if possible
column65: contrive to beat a retreat
column66: helping along the weaker ones as best they can.

column1: A very touching story of the devotion of deer to their fawns comes from America. While two men were riding along a creek in California
column2: they saw
column3: some distance ahead
column4: a doe and her fawn drinking from the river. The bank was very steep
column5: and the river deep at that point. When the deer saw the hunters they were startled
column6: and in trying to turn
column7: the little one lost its balance and fell into the creek. The water was running very swiftly
column8: and of course the fawn was carried down-stream. At this the poor mother seemed to lose all fear of the men
column9: and ran wildly along the bank
column10: trying to reach her little one with her head
column11: but in vain. She next ran forward for a short distance
column12: plunged in
column13: steadied herself by planting her feet firmly among some rocks
column14: and waited. Presently the fawn was washed against her
column15: and
column16: as it was being swept by
column17: caught hold of its mother
column18: stretching out its forelegs and clasping her neck
column19: much as a little child uses his arms in clinging to his nurse. The doe then carefully stepped ashore with her precious burden. She lay down beside the baby deer
column20: and
column21: although the hunters were not thirty yards away
column22: she licked and fondled the little thing till it rose to run
column23: when she too sprang up
column24: and the pair trotted off unharmed to the woods.Many birds use their wings as arms and hands when flight will not serve their turn. A partridge was seen to hustle and drive her little troop of chicks into the shelter of a rabbit-hole with her wings
column25: out of the way of a hawk whose shadow had fallen on the grass at their side. Here she kept them prisoners till all was safe.The lesson to be drawn from such stories is that even wild
column26: untaught creatures do not use their limbs in a senseless way as parts of a machine
column27: without thinking
column28: but are able to turn them to a variety of uses in times of difficulty. We shall
column29: of course
column30: find that tame animals such as the horse
column31: dog
column32: and cat act more wisely in such ways than their wild relations. The dog
column33: for instance
column34: turns his rough idea of using his mouth for carrying food or young ones
column35: to fetching and carrying for his own benefit or his master's. A handsome brown spaniel lately noticed that his mistress
column36: in carrying a bowl of water
column37: upset some of the contents on the floor. Off dashed Master Jack
column38: intent on 'making himself generally useful
column39: ' and quickly returned with the house flannel from the kitchen. This he laid beside the pool
column40: with an intelligent
column41: uplifted look which said
column42: 'There! wipe it up.' Did not this sensible fellow's mouth become a splendid makeshift hand
column43: and his glance an excellent speech? The leaves and flowers of plants often grow into very strange shapes. The flowers of various kinds of orchids are very remarkable for the peculiar forms which they take. Some of them have a great resemblance to bees
column44: flies
column45: or butterflies
column46: and this resemblance is at times so great that we wonder whether it is only an accidental likeness
column47: or whether it serves some useful purpose. One of the oddest shapes which any plant takes
column48: however
column49: is that of the leaves of the pitcher-plant; and in this case naturalists
column50: who have studied the plant carefully
column51: are able to show us that the strange shape of the leaf really serves a purpose.The pitcher-plants are most abundant in the islands of Borneo
column52: Java
column53: and Sumatra
column54: and in the Malay Peninsula. Though not so plentiful elsewhere
column55: they are also found in Ceylon
column56: Madagascar
column57: the Moluccas
column58: and one or two other places. The plant is a kind of creeping or climbing shrub which runs along the ground
column59: or climbs up other shrubs and short trees. It seems to thrive best upon the mountaintops
column60: and the summits of the mountains of Borneo are often gaily decked with it.There are thirty or forty different kinds of pitcher-plants
column61: varying in size a great deal. But the strange thing about all of them is that the ends of their leaves are shaped like pitchers
column62: or perhaps it would describe them better if we said they were like jugs with lids. It is from this peculiarity that the plant takes its name. The leaf is the shape of any ordinary leaf until it reaches its point
column63: where it is drawn out into a long stalk or tendril
column64: at the end of which is the jug or pitcher
column65: which
column66: you must remember
column67: is formed out of the leaf itself. Each plant has its own shape of jug
column68: and the jugs vary in size a good deal. Some are long and slender; others are broad and shallow. Some are tiny jugs only an inch deep
column69: while others are perhaps twenty inches deep. Their colour is green
column70: but the mouth of the jug and the under side of the lid
column71: which is always open
column72: are spotted with red or purple
column73: somewhat like a flower.

column1: Not only do these strange leaves look like jugs
column2: but they are also used as jugs. Each of them contains a little supply of water
column3: varying with the size of the jug from a few drops in the smallest
column4: to as much as two quarts in the largest of them. Thirsty travellers have sometimes quenched their thirst from these natural jugs
column5: when no other water was to be found. Though the water itself is palatable
column6: it is a little warm
column7: and it is always full of insects.If any one were to watch one of these jugs of the pitcher-plant for some time attentively
column8: he would soon find that it served as a trap for flies and insects. One by one the little creatures alight upon the outside of the jug
column9: and creep into the open mouth
column10: and few or none of them ever return. They slip into the water at the bottom of the jug and are drowned.If we examine a jug carefully
column11: in order to learn why the insects enter it
column12: and how it is that they cannot get out again
column13: we shall be surprised at the clever way in which the trap is made. The mouth of the jug has a thick ring round it
column14: which makes it firm
column15: and keeps it always open. The lid stands over this mouth
column16: and seems to be always raised a good deal
column17: so that insects and flies may enter freely; but it covers the mouth in such a way as to prevent anything from falling accidentally into the jug from above. The underside of the lid and the mouth of the jug are often gaily coloured
column18: so as to attract insects
column19: as brightly-coloured flowers do. Some of the jugs even make a little honey
column20: which
column21: forming just inside the mouth
column22: attracts insects by its scent. Within the jug
column23: just below the mouth
column24: there is a row of stiff hooks
column25: which have their points turned inwards towards the bottom of the jug. Below the spikes the sides of the jug are so smooth and slippery that few insects could stand on them.It is easy to see how the trap works. Insects are attracted to the pitcher by the bright colours of the lid or the scent of the honey. They creep into the mouth
column26: and crawl between the hooks
column27: whose sharp points are set the other way
column28: and they step upon the smooth and slippery inside of the jug. In another instant they have slipped into the water at the bottom of the jug. Do what they will
column29: they cannot climb up the slippery sides of the pitcher
column30: or pass the row of sharp hooks
column31: whose points are turned against them. They are caught.Now all this is very strange and wonderful
column32: and it makes us wish to know why Providence has given the plant this clever machinery. We cannot help asking ourselves why the pitcher-plant entraps these insects. I am afraid that you would hardly be able to answer this question for yourself
column33: however carefully you might watch a pitcher-plant. Indeed
column34: it is only a few years since clever men
column35: making careful experiments
column36: were able to find out the real truth. The fluid at the bottom of the pitcher _digests_ those insects
column37: and the pitcher-plant feeds upon them. Just as the juices of our stomach dissolve meat
column38: so that it may pass into the blood and nourish us
column39: so the fluid in the jug of the pitcher-plant dissolves the flesh of the insects which fall into it
column40: and makes that flesh fit to nourish the plant. This strange plant lives
column41: in part at least
column42: upon flesh; and all the clever mechanism of its jug is used simply to get a meal. Two hundred needlewomen were busy for a month making the 'Giant's' coat. It contained twenty thousand yards of white silk
column43: of double thickness
column44: at six shillings a yard
column45: and when finished measured ninety yards round and sixty yards in height. When it was filled it held 6098 cubic yards of gas. M. Nadar
column46: its master
column47: introduced it to the people of Paris in the hope that the money they would pay to see it would enable him to carry out his experiments with flying machines. On October 4th
column49: the Giant was ready to make its first voyage in the clouds
column50: and nearly five hundred thousand people assembled to see it start.

column1: It was like a cottage made of wicker-work
column2: and mounted on small wheels. In two of the four walls there was a door with two small windows each side of it
column3: and inside there was a little world of wonders. The 'cottage' was only fifteen feet long
column4: twelve wide
column5: and eight high; but it was divided up so carefully by thin partitions that there was room for a small printing-office
column6: a photographic department
column7: a refreshment-room
column8: a compartment for the captain's bed and passengers' luggage
column9: and another at the opposite end
column10: with three beds in it. Outside all this
column11: but inside the walls of wicker-work
column12: was an inflated rubber lining
column13: so as to prevent it from sinking if
column14: by any mischance
column15: the 'Giant' should fall into the sea. Thus

column18: a ship at sea
column19: or a caravan being drawn by horses upon the wheels already mentioned along a country road. From the inside a narrow stairway led on to the roof
column20: or deck.When all was ready
column21: M. Nadar
column22: leaning from the deck
column23: gave the word. The ropes were let go
column24: and the Giant rose solemnly towards the sky. Fifteen voyagers waved their hats and handkerchiefs over the bulwarks
column25: returning the greetings of the crowd till carried beyond sight and hearing.Though the launch was a success
column26: the poor Giant had been served very badly by some careless persons
column27: all unknown to those on board. The pilot
column28: a clever aeronaut
column29: named Godard
column30: was a little surprised that very soon after leaving the ground he had to begin throwing out ballast
column31: to stop them from sinking. This went on for some hours
column32: and when darkness had fallen
column33: and all the world had disappeared
column34: it became clear that the balloon must descend. They had attained a height of many thousand feet. It was nearly nine o'clock
column35: and supper on deck was over
column36: when Godard
column37: finding that the descent was becoming too rapid
column38: called out
column39: 'Hold to the ropes!'Every passenger seized some portion of the ropes
column40: so that the shock of contact with the earth might be somewhat lessened. Down came the Giant
column41: a great deal more swiftly than it had risen; and the last bags of ballast were emptied over the side with little effect. The blow was tremendous
column42: and the wonder is that the passengers escaped with their lives. An inquiry was held
column43: and the Giant itself was proved blameless. The valves for allowing the escape of gas had never been properly closed! Thus
column44: from the very moment when they left Paris
column45: the gas was pouring out at the top; and it was only through the enormous quantity used that they succeeded in rising at all.A fortnight later M. Nadar was ready to sail again. This time the Giant had nine passengers
column46: who were destined to make an eventful voyage. Anchor was weighed in the evening
column47: and very soon
column48: at a great height
column49: all eyes were turned to watch the beautiful sunset. As the shadows of night gathered round them
column50: however
column51: more than one traveller looked anxiously at the gigantic ball above. Supposing anything should go wrong with it! It looked such a tremendous distance down to the earth.When day dawned again at last
column52: after a night during which no one had closed his eyes
column53: they found themselves hanging over the fens of Holland
column54: many miles from Paris. Fearing that the wind might carry them out to sea
column55: they agreed to descend. But
column56: on reaching the lower air
column57: the huge balloon was caught in what proved to be almost a hurricane. It drove them towards the ground at a long angle
column58: until
column59: like a falling kite
column60: the Giant struck the earth head foremost
column61: dragging the car behind it at a terrible speed. The travellers hung on for dear life. Again and again the car struck
column62: and rebounded thirty or forty feet into the air. With the first blow the valve-rope was jerked beyond reach
column63: so that it became impossible to let the gas escape.

column1: Mile after mile they tore through the country
column2: crashing into trees
column3: and scattering herds of cattle right and left. All the anchor-ropes
column4: dropped one after the other
column5: had been snapped like thread
column6: the last catching in the roof of a cottage
column7: and tearing it open before giving way. Then
column8: to the horror of the passengers
column9: a railway-train appeared a short distance ahead
column10: spinning along at great speed. A collision seemed inevitable; but with one united effort they shouted to the driver. He heard them
column11: and reversed his engine
column12: and the next moment they whirled by
column13: dragging telegraph wires and poles after them. And now a hero came to their rescue. Jules Godard
column14: the pilot's brother
column15: after many fruitless attempts

column20: the Giant took a short sea voyage on board a real ship
column21: and crossed the Channel to England
column22: and
column23: blown out with harmless air

column25: and ended its career as a poor captive balloon in the gardens of Cremorne.As there was nothing to detain Charlie in the galley he went forward to assist in hauling. The skipper was on the bridge; the mate was working the donkey-engine
column26: which was fast drawing in the long wire ropes attached to the net

column29: so that the men could see to do the work they had in hand. For a moment or two Charlie stood at the foot of the bridge
column30: waiting for the skipper or the mate to tell him what to do.Charlie nodded his head and took up his position about three feet away from the Chinaman. Soon the net appeared above water
column31: and the men
column32: bending over the gunwale
column33: grasped it with their hands
column34: and
column35: tugging all together
column36: pulled it slowly but surely upwards.'For'ard
column37: ' Ping Wang answered
column38: and as he spoke the donkey-engine started panting and puffing
column39: and the part of the net to which the Chinaman had pointed was now raised high above the gunwale. It resembled a huge cooking-net which had been lifted out of a gigantic pan. It was crowded with fish
column40: and as it was pulled in and suspended over the pound made on the deck
column41: the very small fish
column42: mostly dead
column43: fell through. Others
column44: with wide-opened mouths
column45: were caught in the meshes. A fisherman now stepped under the dripping net
column46: untied it at the bottom
column47: and sprang quickly aside as the catch of fish fell with a thud into the pound.'Cod
column48: plaice
column49: haddock
column50: and turbot
column51: ' Ping Wang replied

column53: sole
column54: whiting

column59: whelks

column62: and a large amount of ocean scrapings.Charlie bestirred himself at once
column63: and assisted in shooting the gear. When that had been done without a hitch
column64: the work of sorting
column65: cleaning
column66: and packing the fish was begun. Three men stepped into the pound

column1: The plaice were the only ones which had not to be cut open. As each fish was cleaned it was tossed into another pound
column2: and when the whole of the catch
column3: with the exception of the plaice
column4: oysters
column5: whelks
column6: and the useless fish
column7: were in this

column9: and therefore he hurried to the bucket
column10: on which was painted 'All hands
column11: ' and indulged in a wash. He was fortunate in being first
column12: for fresh water is not plentiful on a trawler
column13: and one bucketful has to suffice for the whole crew.'Cook is one of the right sort
column14: after all
column15: ' one of the fishermen declared as he returned his empty mug to Charlie
column16: and the others assented by nods and grunts. But before long Charlie was again in hot water. As he was assisting to haul in the net he sneezed loudly. In a moment one of the fishermen placed his big
column17: dirty hand over his mouth and effectually prevented him from sneezing on the net again.'It is thought very unlucky to sneeze on a trawl
column18: ' the mate explained quietly
column19: anxious to save Charlie from any further bullying. 'It is supposed to bring bad luck to the trawler. Now
column20: grab hold of the net.'Charlie returned to the galley
column21: hardly knowing whether to be angry or amused. It was very galling to have to submit to the abuse of an ignorant
column22: blustering fellow like the skipper
column23: but
column24: at the same time
column25: he could not take the man's superstition seriously.'I would not have believed
column26: unless I had seen the skipper
column27: that it was possible for there to be such a superstitious Briton living at the end of the nineteenth century
column28: ' Charlie said to the mate
column29: about half an hour later.'Oh
column30: there are many like him in the North Sea
column31: ' the mate answered
column32: 'and all the arguing in the world won't convince them of their foolishness. After a time you will not find his ignorance and superstition amusing. However
column33: what I want to say to you is this: the men in the foc's'le declare that the grub isn't well cooked
column34: and that you haven't given them plum duff yet. You must let them have it to-morrow.'When the mate left him
column35: Charlie took out the bow-legged cook's written instructions to see what ingredients were necessary. His idea was to make and boil the pudding that evening
column36: so that
column37: if it turned out a failure
column38: he would have time to make another one. If it proved to be a success
column39: he would be able to warm it up on the following morning. But
column40: just as he began to read the recipe
column41: he noticed that the fire had burnt low and needed instant attention. In his anxiety to prevent it from going out
column42: he put down the flimsy little book and began shovelling coals on the fire. While he was doing that a gust of wind swept through the galley
column43: and carried the recipe-book out through the porthole and into the sea. The kitchen was very hot
column44: and Aunt Christy
column45: the old black cook
column46: was very busy. With her sleeves rolled up above her elbows
column47: and her cap all awry
column48: she bustled about
column49: hurrying the slow movements of the girls who were her helpers
column50: and scolding the four little dusky children whenever they got in her way. She declared that they were all as full of mischief as they could be
column51: and that there was not a pin to choose between them. But if one of the four _did_ happen to be worse than the others
column52: that one was certainly Jim.Jim was nearly seven; his young mind was full of eager questions; he wanted to know the reason of everything
column53: and it was really because he was so curious and prying that Aunt Christy thought him worse than the rest.So said Jim to himself; and when he found that
column54: even by standing on tiptoe
column55: he could not reach
column56: the little rascal trotted off for his three-legged stool
column57: mounted on that
column58: put his chubby arms as far as they would stretch round the pail. A three-legged stool
column59: however
column60: is but a treacherous support
column61: and this Jim found to his cost. As he stood there
column62: it slipped from under his bare feet
column63: and the pail
column64: which was full of warm water and vegetables
column65: suddenly overturned.

column1: An omnibus
column2: in the course of its journey
column3: had to be taken up a long and toilsome hill. Frequently passengers
column4: out of pity for the poor horse

column1: Fig. 1.--Aphis, showing "Trache" (greatly magnified). Fig. 2.--"Tracheal Filaments" of Aphis (greatly magnified). Fig. 3.--"Spiracles" of Water Beetle (greatly magnified). Fig. 4.--Section of Crayfish, showing gills (magnified).] Animal life cannot be sustained without breathing, though, strange as it may seem, many of the lower animals have no special breathing organs. By breathing, we mean supplying the body with the life-giving oxygen contained in the air. Animals which live in the water breathe by taking in the oxygen held in solution in the water.In the simplest animals which live in water, the body is only a small 'blob' of jelly, so small that the oxygen passes directly into the body. The bodies of some worms are so delicate that the oxygen easily passes through the outer layers and mixes with the blood within.In more complicated animals this life-giving gas is conveyed all over the body by means of the blood, which is brought into contact with the water, or the air, by structures known as gills. In the crayfish, for example, the gills are placed above and rise from the bases of the legs, being saved from injury by a broad shield lying behind the head. (In fig. 4 this shield has been cut away so as to show the gills, marked G, which it really covers.) By means of the circulation of the blood, the crayfish breathes. This blood is carried to the gills and bathed by a constant stream of fresh water, which enters behind the covering and shield, and passes forwards till it comes out on each side of the mouth. The blood, thus refreshed by the oxygen in the water, is carried again all over the body, and in its course loses more and more oxygen, and becomes more and more charged with poisonous gases, which are got rid of on the return of the blood to the gills. The letter S in this figure marks the stump of the leg, which, for the sake of clearness, has been cut off.In ourselves, the work of breathing, or of purifying the blood, is done by means of the lungs. The lungs are large, spongy organs in the chest, and are continually supplied with fresh air, which passes in through the nose and mouth and down the wind-pipe, by what we call the act of breathing.Insects take in oxygen in a way quite different from that of the crayfish or mankind. In some larval insects, which live in water, as in some worms, the body is so thin that no special breathing organs are necessary; others breathe by means of gills like those of the crayfish, but arranged differently--sometimes along each side, and sometimes at the tail end of the body. But in the ordinary adult insect the work of breathing is carried on by means of a system of tubes, known as 'trache,' which run all over the body. Into these tubes the air is drawn through a number of holes on the surface of the body, called 'spiracles,' or breathing pores. The trache or tubes are everywhere bathed by the blood, which is thus constantly 'aerated,' or kept fresh.One very remarkable thing about these tubes is the way they are kept open. A horny, spirally-twisted thread runs through them, and thus they are prevented from closing up by pressure, or by the bending of the body or limbs. In fig. 2, this thread is marked C. This plan of keeping open the passage in a tube likely to be blocked by sudden bending, has been imitated by mankind, in making rubber gas tubing, for example. As a plain rubber tube is easily bent, the gas would be in constant danger of being cut off. To prevent this, Nature's patent is usually imitated, and a coil of wire is placed along the inside of the tube. Thus, a sharp bend, such as would instantly obstruct the passage of the gas, is prevented.
The openings at the end of the breathing tubes
column2: on the surface of the insect's body
column3: are known
column4: as we have said
column5: as 'spiracles
column6: ' or 'stigmata.' They can be closed at will by special muscles
column7: and
