column66: had come to the conclusion that he also ought to do something. He dived in
column67: but in consequence of the muddled state of his head
column68: swam in the wrong direction
column69: and by the time that it dawned on him that he had made a mistake his mate had been rescued by Charlie.'You've had a very narrow escape
column70: ' Charlie said to the man whom he had rescued. 'Now take my advice
column71: both of you
column72: and don't you ever again set foot on a coper. If you want tobacco
column73: go to a mission ship.'

column1: Charlie got on the seat as he finished speaking
column2: and as the little boat was lifted on a big wave he sprang upwards
column3: grasped the _Lily's_ gunwale and climbed aboard
column4: leaving the men to whom he had denounced copers to wonder why he was on one. Loud blasts from their trawler's siren instantly drove all thoughts of Charlie's action from their minds
column5: and rowing hard they worked their way back to their ship
column6: where they received a lecture from the skipper which they did not forget that voyage. Many years ago there was a clever and kind doctor at a Paris hospital where the patients were of the poorest class. The skill of this doctor somehow reached the ears of the then Premier of France
column7: who
column8: being about to undergo a very serious operation
column9: sent for this doctor to perform it.'You must not expect
column10: doctor
column11: ' said the Prime Minister to the surgeon as he entered the room to arrange for the operation
column12: 'to treat me in the same rough manner as if I were one of your poor wretches at the hospital.' In the days of Queen Bess the pretty village of Stoke Newington was a pleasant object for a country walk of about three miles from the City boundary of London. The village lay amid dense woods whence came its name--Stoe being the Saxon word for wood
column13: and Stoke Newington meaning the new town in the wood. Its derivation shows what an old place it is
column14: and we may picture to ourselves how
column15: ages ago
column16: the dwellers within the City walls would joyfully leave London
column17: on holidays
column18: by the Moor Gate
column19: and wend their way northward to the shady trees and grassy banks of the roadway known as the 'Green Lanes'--names which
column20: like Stoke Newington
column21: still survive. Along that road the royal chariot of Queen Elizabeth might occasionally be met coming from the Tower; for at Stoke Newington
column22: in a mansion beside the church
column23: dwelt some of the Dudley family
column24: whom she delighted to honour.A story is told how
column25: when her Majesty was the persecuted Princess Elizabeth
column26: living under the stern rule of her sister
column27: Queen Mary
column28: she paid a stolen visit to London to see how Court matters were progressing. The Dudleys befriended her
column29: and went so far as to hide her in a brick tower in the Park
column30: communicating with their home by a secret passage. To judge by what history tells of Queen Mary
column31: these devoted friends ran no slight risk
column32: and Queen Elizabeth
column33: in later years
column34: did her best to repay their kindness. We read that
column35: on one visit after her accession
column36: she took a jewel of great value from her dress and presented it to the daughter of the house
column37: Lady Anne Dudley. One avenue off the Park is still known as Queen Elizabeth's Walk
column38: and tradition says she was fond of pacing up and down there with the master of the house.The next time we hear much of Stoke Newington Park
column39: it was in the hands of Mr. Jonathan Hoare
column40: one of the founders of the great banking house of that name; and
column41: later still
column42: it was rented from the Ecclesiastical Commissioners by one of the Crawshay family
column43: then known as 'the iron princes' of Wales. His lease set forth that he was to pay the sum of one hundred and nine pounds a year rent
column44: with one good
column45: fat turkey
column46: the latter probably appearing at the annual dinner of his landlords. For this consideration he was allowed to call house and land after his own name
column47: but was forbidden to cut down timber. Mr. Crawshay's tenancy closed romantically with the incident which won the place its present title.He had two fair daughters
column48: whom no doubt he wished to see married to rich and noble husbands. Great
column49: therefore
column50: was his anger when he found that one of them had given her affections to the curate of the parish
column51: Mr. Clissold by name. Mr. Clissold was forthwith forbidden to set foot within Crawshay Farm again. To ensure this
column52: the walls of the place were made higher
column53: and the hard-hearted parent expressed his firm resolve of shooting any messenger who tried to carry letters secretly. How long this state of affairs lasted does not appear
column54: but it was ended by the death of Mr. Crawshay. Then the curate and his hardly-won bride became tenants of the mansion
column55: and changed its name to Clissold Park or Place.Perhaps the greatest charm of this particular park lies in its evident old age--trees
column56: turf
column57: and the disused mansion all bear witness that it is no newly planted recreation ground
column58: but a noble relic of the days of old
column59: with a stately dignity all its own.A number of deer enclosed in the middle of the park prove that these pretty creatures are not always shy. A family of kittens could not be less afraid of the admiring crowd which watches them. At the same time the deer were presented to the park
column60: a number of guinea-pigs were also introduced
column61: and they still flourish in their cosy enclosure
column62: giving endless delight to the children of the neighbourhood.The beauty of the park is greatly increased by the waters of the New River
column63: which wind in and out of the grounds as well as round them
column64: although the charm of the stream is somewhat spoilt by a close iron fencing
column65: walling in the water on both sides. This
column66: however
column67: appears to be a necessity
column68: to protect the numerous fish from the keenness of would-be fishermen.

column1: Bridges cross the river in many places
column2: and two lakes of some size
column3: studded with wooded islets
column4: afford homes for swans
column5: ducks
column6: and other water-fowl. Near the mansion there is a bandstand
column7: and all about the grounds there are seats and rustic shelters for the elders
column8: whilst the young folk and children are making merry with games.In the spring and autumn a very favourite place for basking in the sun is the terrace before the old house
column9: in part of which refreshments are provided. Some of the views in the park are exceedingly pretty
column10: especially in the direction of the deer park
column11: looking towards the mansion
column12: where the old parish church stands out against the trees
column13: whilst the fine open tower of a new church
column14: with a graceful spire
column15: rises above the green foliage.Stoke Newington has been the home of various celebrated men: John Howard
column16: the philanthropist
column17: who did so much to alleviate the horrors of prison-life; Defoe
column18: whom we all love for the sake of _Robinson Crusoe_; Dr. Watts
column19: author of many of our best-known hymns
column20: among the number.It is pleasant to know that the leafy walk of the Green Lanes is still an attractive one for Londoners
column21: although the mossy banks of former days have long been lined with handsome houses
column22: and though a wide expanse of densely populated town lies between Clissold Park and the street still known as London Wall
column23: whence the Moor Gate
column24: with all its companion portals
column25: have long vanished. A gentleman was once entertaining his friends at a grand dinner. He was a sad boaster
column26: and was often guilty of describing deeds that he had done when an officer in the army
column27: which those who knew him well felt sure were greatly exaggerated. He was in the midst of some such anecdote when the butler brought him word that a man wished to see him.The butler retired
column28: but soon came back to say the man was most urgent in wishing to speak to the gentleman
column29: and said he had been in his regiment at a famous battle
column30: where he owed his life to the officer.'Show him in! show him in!' said the host
column31: much gratified. 'This good fellow says I saved his life at X----
column32: ' he added
column33: turning to his guests as the old soldier came in. 'How was it?' he went on
column34: 'for I am sure I forget; in the heat of battle one does brave things almost unconsciously.' It is comparatively easy now to run over to Switzerland
column35: and through the lovely scenery of the St. Gothard Pass
column36: to the plains of sunny Italy; but this land of light and song is very little known to English boys and girls.Of all the lovely lakes that reflect the deep blue of the summer skies
column37: none is more beautiful than Lake Lugano
column38: although Como is larger and Maggiore has a charm of its own. The town of Lugano stands at one end of the lake. It is pretty and bright
column39: with many things to interest and amuse; but it is in the villages dotted along the south side of the lake that the real life of the people is to be seen.These villages are surrounded by vineyards. The grapes are gathered in October
column40: when the whole scene is very animated and gay. Every one--men
column41: women
column42: children
column43: even the ox-waggons of the country--is pressed into the service
column44: and the vineyards resound with songs and laughter. From these grapes a red wine is made. It is the ambition of every peasant to own a small vineyard and a boat.On the other side of the lake rises a range of hills covered almost to the water's edge with deep green woods. In some places cliffs rise between wood and water
column45: and in these cliffs are many small natural caves. These have been enlarged and enclosed with doors
column46: so as to form wine vaults
column47: and in them is stored much of the wine made in the district.On Sunday afternoons in summer the lake is alive with boats
column48: each holding a happy family party of father
column49: mother
column50: and children
column51: and laden with cakes made from _polenta_
column52: and other dainties. They are all bound for the caves
column53: where a series of merry picnic parties is soon in progress.

column1: The provisions are taken from the boats
column2: the wine vault is opened with a key
column3: for all are kept carefully locked
column4: and then the feast begins. Soon the air is filled with song and laughter. The whole afternoon is spent in this way
column5: and only in the cool of the evening do the merry revellers return to their simple homes across the lake.The boats look very pretty. They are rather wide and shallow
column6: and in the middle a white canvas covering is stretched from side to side
column7: supported on bent canes
column8: to make a shelter from the heat of the sun. The boatman in the dress of the country stands at the end
column9: and drives the boat through the water with rapid strokes from his single oar.The streets are narrow and crooked
column10: and the houses are built very irregularly. There is no pavement
column11: and the dust is amazing. The brown-faced
column12: bare-legged children
column13: with large solemn-looking brown eyes
column14: tumble about in it
column15: munching ripe red tomatoes with their hunches of brown bread. In the grass by the road-side funny little green lizards run in and out
column16: hurrying away at your approach as fast as their legs will carry them.It is very strange to see even the smallest cottages fitted with electric light
column17: but this is the case in one village
column18: Marroggia. A clever German has set up some works close by
column19: and drives the machinery by power derived from a beautiful waterfall near the village.From Marroggia a young Italian went to London some years ago to seek his fortune. He succeeded so well that he soon became rich. Returning to his native village
column20: he built there a beautiful villa
column21: with gardens and lawns sloping down to the lake. When it was finished he gave a feast to all the villagers. Thousands of fairy lamps and Chinese lanterns were sent for from London to illuminate the gardens
column22: and turn them for the occasion into fairyland. The peasants had never before seen anything like it. They danced
column23: they sang
column24: and ate the good things provided for them. They would willingly have lingered there all night
column25: and it was only when the last lamp flickered and went out that they returned home to dream of what they had enjoyed.At one end of the lake stands Monte Generoso. The top is reached by a mountain railway
column26: which zig-zags its way up through the woods. It feels very strange as the engine goes up panting and puffing
column27: turning a sharp corner at every few yards; but the view from the summit is very fine
column28: and the journey down still more exciting than the ascent.At the other end of the lake is a famous china and earthenware manufactory. You can reach it by steamboat
column29: but it is much better fun to go in a small boat
column30: where you can lie under the awning and watch the boatman
column31: in his white shirt-sleeves and coloured velvet waistcoat
column32: steering his boat like the gondoliers of Venice.The china manufactory is old-fashioned
column33: but very interesting. The potter's wheel is still used there
column34: and it is wonderful to see the ease and quickness with which a lump of clay is made into a cup
column35: a saucer
column36: a vase
column37: or any other article you may ask for. After it is taken off the wheel
column38: it is dipped into liquid glaze
column39: then ornamented with some design transferred from coloured paper
column40: and finally fired in the furnace.Most people who visit the Italian lakes go on to Milan
column41: a very important
column42: busy town. On the way you pass through large tracts of country covered with maize and rice fields. The maize grows to an enormous height
column43: and the rice is watered artificially by tiny streams
column44: which may be seen trickling through the fields in all directions.

column1: Towards the close of the war between France and Germany
column3: the German troops lay so closely round the walls and fortifications of Paris that all communication with the outside world was cut off. No letters could be sent to friends
column4: and no letters from friends could be received
column5: for
column6: once outside the walls of the town
column7: they would surely fall into the hands of the enemy. But the post office was anxious to continue doing its duty
column8: and the Government felt bound to find some means for sending out and receiving official dispatches. The only way to accomplish this was by the use of balloons. Paris had always been very busy with balloons
column9: but
column10: when inquiries were made
column11: it was found that there were not more than six in all the city
column12: and these were far too old and worn out to use. Balloons must
column13: therefore
column14: be made
column15: said the authorities
column16: and two gentlemen
column17: named Godard and Yon
column18: were requested to begin the work at once. As railway stations were not wanted for trains in Paris at that particular time
column19: the two largest were chosen in which to build balloons. Henceforth their 'trains' would journey silently through the sky instead of noisily over the iron roads.Needles and cotton and calico were all carried in large quantities to the Gare du Nord and the Gare d'Orlans (as the two stations are called)
column20: and in less than four months sixty balloons were built and dispatched.Some people in Paris
column21: however
column22: were so anxious to try the experiment that they could not wait for the new balloons
column23: but used an old one
column24: called the 'Neptune
column25: ' and M. Durnof
column26: a daring aeronaut
column27: made a flying dash in it out of Paris. Those who witnessed his adventure say that the old Neptune bounded almost straight up into the air
column28: and fell beyond the enemy's camp in much the same manner. It was as though a large cannon ball had been fired (only very slowly) from the streets of Paris.The successful path of the Neptune was soon followed. M. Gambetta
column29: the great statesman
column30: stepped into the car of the 'Armand Barbs' on the morning of October 7th
column31: and
column32: after many narrow escapes from the enemy's guns
column33: landed safely among friends. Three days later a pretty grey-feathered pigeon settled in Paris
column34: bringing in one of its quills the story of his journey.But among the many wonderful ascents made in that terrible time
column35: none is more interesting than that of M. Janssen
column36: a great astronomer
column37: who went to Algeria to see an eclipse of the sun. Certain learned societies in France
column38: very anxious that the progress of science should not be delayed by this unhappy war
column39: were delighted to find him willing to undertake the dangerous journey. England offered to obtain a safe-conduct for him through the Prussian camp
column40: but the astronomer said: 'No
column41: thank you. I do not wish to be under any obligation to the enemy.'So
column42: packing his telescope and other instruments with very great care
column43: he carried them to the Gare d'Orlans on the morning of the 2nd December (three weeks before the eclipse would take place)
column44: and
column45: settling himself in the car of his white balloon
column46: the 'Volta
column47: ' gave orders for the anchor to be weighed. At that time in the morning it was quite dark
column48: and
column49: ere daylight was an hour old
column50: he and his companion (a young sailor) had come to earth again by the mouth of the Loire. They had travelled nearly three hundred miles in a little more than three hours. A swifter journey has hardly ever been made. It is disappointing to learn that
column51: after such a daring exploit
column52: M. Janssen reached his destination only to find dense clouds covering the Algerian sky at the moment the eclipse took place.The frequency with which balloons left Paris soon made it necessary to increase the number of aeronauts
column53: for those who departed were
column54: of course
column55: unable to return. As the professional men became fewer
column56: it was found that the best to take their places were sailors. But
column57: that they might first have lessons in the art
column58: a car was suspended from the roof of the factory
column59: and into this the sailor-pupil climbed. He soon learned how to cry out
column60: 'Let go all!' Then
column61: after throwing out the ballast
column62: pulling the valve-rope
column63: and dropping the anchor
column64: he was ready
column65: with more courage than discretion
column66: to call himself an aeronaut. And into the air he went
column67: with bags of letters and cages of pigeons
column68: and
column69: on the whole
column70: succeeded very well as a postman in the clouds.

column1: After the question of how to dispatch letters had been solved
column2: the next that arose was
column3: how to receive replies. The balloons that _left_ the city had got nearly all Europe to settle in
column4: but it was hopeless to try to steer them back to so small a spot as the city itself. But a carrier pigeon would have no such difficulty in returning. Means must be found
column5: however
column6: to make it possible for each bird to carry many letters. M. Dagron
column7: a clever photographer
column8: discovered this means. He showed how he could photograph a letter and reduce it in size till the writing became unreadable
column9: even under an ordinary magnifying glass. This could be done on films so thin that a roll of twenty of them could be inserted in one quill
column10: each film representing a large number of letters. Having proved to the authorities the success of his invention
column11: M. Dagron departed in a balloon
column12: to explain to the various towns in France how letters must be sent to Paris.Every day after that the welcome sounds of flapping wings was heard in the beleaguered city. The letters that they brought were placed between two sheets of glass and enlarged. Then
column13: by means of a magic lantern
column14: they were reflected on to a large screen
column15: while post-office clerks
column16: sitting at a table opposite
column17: copied them down on to separate sheets
column18: and dispatched them to their different addresses in the city. Nearly one hundred thousand letters were sent to Paris in this way during the four months of the siege
column19: and the hostile army outside its walls was powerless to intercept them. Willie laid his pencil down
column20: And put his books away
column21: And with a sad and peevish frown He hurried out to play. But as he ran
column22: the blackbird's song From poplars in the lane
column23: Rang out: 'You know that sum was wrong
column24: And should be done again.' Yet Willie heeded not the sound; Pretended not to hear
column25: Till trees
column26: and hills and all around Kept singing in his ear: 'It's no use
column27: Willie! Trust us
column28: do! You can't enjoy the fun Until the task that's set for you Is well and justly done.' Then in a sad and sorry state He homeward turned amain: Took up his pencil and his slate And worked the sum again. _This_ time the answer wasn't wrong
column29: And as to play he went
column30: His conscience sang an altered song Which made his heart content. A father of a family wished to settle his property between his three sons. He therefore made three equal parts of his chief possessions and gave one part to each son. There remained over a diamond ring of great value
column31: which he reserved for the son who should perform the noblest and most generous action within the space of three months. The sons separated
column32: and at the appointed time presented themselves before him.The eldest son said
column33: 'Father
column34: during my absence I had in my power all the riches and fortune of a person who entrusted them to me without any security of any kind; he asked me for them
column35: and I returned them to him with the greatest honesty.''You have done
column36: my son
column37: ' replied the father
column38: 'only what was your duty
column39: and I should die of shame if you were capable of doing otherwise
column40: for honesty is a duty; what you did was just
column41: but not generous.'It was now the second son's turn
column42: and he spoke thus: 'I was on the banks of a lake
column43: when
column44: seeing a child fall in
column45: I threw myself in
column46: and with great danger to myself drew him out. I did it in the presence of some countrymen
column47: who will testify to the truth of it.'At last came the turn of the third son
column48: who spoke thus: 'I found my mortal enemy
column49: who had strayed during the night
column50: and was sleeping on the edge of a precipice in such a manner that the least false movement on waking would have thrown him over. His life was in my hands; I was careful to wake him with precaution
column51: and drew him out of danger.' 'The stork in the heavens knoweth her appointed times
column52: ' says the Bible
column53: and the turtle-dove
column54: the crane
column55: and the swallow to this day 'observe the time of their coming.' What a wonderful law is theirs! They need not learn it
column56: for it is born in them. Migratory birds know not only the need for their journeys
column57: but the fixed times for them. It has been thought that the rules of their airy road have been handed down from generation to generation
column58: but this is not always true. Nothing is positively known
column59: except that the travellers are in search of food or quiet nesting-places
column60: when they move from land to land.

column1: As the time draws near for birds of passage to travel
column2: they seem to know it by an inward restlessness; they long to be away--they know that delay is dangerous
column3: and
column4: so strong is the longing to be gone
column5: that migratory birds kept back by accident or wilful cruelty
column6: often die of the desire to go. The young cuckoo never survives an attempt to detain him. A poor
column7: wild goose
column8: with a lame wing
column9: was seen bravely setting out on foot to do his journey of hundreds of miles over sea and land
column10: when he saw his brethren depart for another clime.One of nature's grandest sights is the yearly flight southwards of wild swans from Norway to the great lakes in Turkey. The birds fly at the rate of about one hundred miles an hour
column11: in vast flocks
column12: shaped like the letter V
column13: the sharp end foremost
column14: as an arrow passes through the air. At the point flies the leader or captain
column15: the strongest and wisest of the band
column16: and ahead of the main army he sends a skirmishing swan to keep a sharp look-out. This swan's business it is to see if the coast is clear. From time to time he comes rushing back with some warning note. Then there is a great cackling
column17: a pause
column18: and a council. After holding this noisy parliament
column19: the army resumes its course
column20: or changes it
column21: according to the news brought. When the swans reach the lake
column22: they do not swoop down till the captain has made a careful search around
column23: poking among the reeds
column24: flapping over the surface
column25: and even taking a sip of the water
column26: to make sure that nothing has happened to make the lake dangerous for swans since the last time he was there. All being well
column27: he signals to the band
column28: who descend with a rush
column29: and soon cover the water with their graceful forms.Do pigeons carry watches? How do London pigeons
column30: for instance
column31: tell the hour
column32: and turn up punctually at the feeding-places? At Guildhall Yard the birds come early in the morning to eat the breakfast provided for them
column33: but they do not stay all day. At Finsbury Circus
column34: Draper's Hall Gardens
column35: and other places in London
column36: there are flocks which are carefully fed at regular hours
column37: and those who have the care of them agree that at feeding-time the flocks are always joined by large numbers of guests from without. Perhaps the pigeons ask each other out to dine
column38: mentioning the hours for the meals!The rough idea of time which all living things possess is keenest in domestic animals. The dogs
column39: cats
column40: horses
column41: donkeys
column42: and others
column43: who know certain days in the week and hours in the day without clock or almanac
column44: may be guided by noticing little events which we do not
column45: but which show them the time; or they may even feel the position of the sun
column46: though it cannot be seen. However this may be
column47: they show a sense which we must admire and may envy. Horses are great observers of time
column48: as many anecdotes show
column49: perhaps none better than this one: A horse belonging to a news-man knew the houses at which his master's journals were delivered
column50: and
column51: when he took them round in the trap
column52: always stopped at the right doors. But this was not all. There were two people--living one at Thorpe
column53: the other at Chertsey--who paid for a weekly paper between them
column54: taking it in turns to read it first. The horse found this out
column55: and would stop one week at Thorpe and the next at Chertsey
column56: alternately.The mule is not behindhand. A Spanish milk-seller was taken ill
column57: and
column58: being unable to go the rounds or to spare his wife
column59: they agreed to send the mule
column60: who always carried it
column61: alone. A paper was written
column62: asking the customers to measure their own milk
column63: and place the money in a little can for the purpose; this was fastened to the animal's neck
column64: and off he went. At every house where his master was in the habit of selling milk he stopped and waited; but _he did not wait an unreasonable time_. If nobody came
column65: he tried to push the door open
column66: or pulled the string of the bell
column67: which
column68: in Madrid
column69: is usually rung by a cord hanging down. The simple peasants laughed
column70: and fell into the joke; they scorned to cheat the dumb milkman
column71: and the clever mule took his money home in triumph.

column1: It is not the higher animals alone who are time-keepers. Menault tells of a friendly toad
column2: living in a garden
column3: who would appear at the family dinner-time
column4: and sit upon the stone ledge outside the window to get a share. The hour was changed
column5: for some reason
column6: from noon to three in the afternoon
column7: and
column8: for the first time
column9: the uninvited guest was absent--once
column10: but once only. On the second day after the change he was squatting at the new hour ready for his saucer of milk. Three days passed
column11: and Charlie and Ping Wang were still on board the coper
column12: no boat bound for Grimsby having been met. During that time Charlie and his friend had seen many things which filled them with loathing for the boat on which circumstances had placed them.On the third evening
column13: when the coper's boat returned from a trip around the trawlers
column14: Charlie and Ping Wang were surprised to see that the passengers were two men who had been sent away early on the previous evening
column15: because their money was spent.'They've borrowed from their mates
column16: ' Ping Wang suggested
column17: but they soon discovered that his explanation was not the right one. As the boat bobbed up and down by the side of the _Lily_
column18: the men took from the bottom of it a fishing-net
column19: and handed it up to the skipper
column20: who was leaning over the gunwale.The two men descended at once into the saloon
column21: while the skipper
column22: after examining the net
column23: dragged it aft
column24: and removing a hatchway dropped the net into the hold. As he did so Charlie stepped forward
column25: and looking down
column26: saw
column27: by the light of the wire-guarded lamp
column28: that the hold was half full of nets
column29: oars
column30: buckets
column31: ropes
column32: cooking utensils
column33: brass fittings
column34: mops
column35: oilies
column36: and other things too numerous to mention.Forgetting all about Charlie
column37: the skipper hurried away to look at the new craft
column38: and found that the news was true. Very bad news he considered it
column39: for he knew that the North Sea fishermen never came aboard a coper if there was a mission ship with the fleet. Tobacco is sold cheaper on a mission ship than on a coper
column40: and naturally the fishermen
column41: who have very little money to spend
column42: buy in the cheapest market. Moreover
column43: every man aboard a mission ship is a friend of the fishermen
column44: and there is not a trawler in the North Sea on which it is not possible to find two or three men who have good reasons for blessing mission ships. Hundreds of men have been carried aboard these floating hospitals and nursed back to health.The skipper
column45: however
column46: had no intention of keeping on board two men without money
column47: and was compelled to wait about for their departure. But just as he expected them to go
column48: one man had a heated argument with his companion
column49: which ended in a fight. The skipper
column50: fearing that his saloon might be damaged
column51: tried to stop the fight by seizing hold of the smaller man

column1: 'I know, but that has only made them more anxious to go. It is another case of "like father like son." If I had not travelled while young, I am sure I should never have settled down. And the fact that in every place I visited I found scores of Englishmen yearning to return home made me feel that I was a fortunate man to see our distant possessions without being doomed to pass my life in exile. I have sufficient money to keep a home for my children, but I want my sons to be able to earn a living and hold their own by themselves; and I think that, as I have the means to permit them to travel before settling down, they will do well to learn as much as they can of the world outside England. They shall go with Ping Wang. If they help Ping Wang to secure his inheritance, I shall of course be pleased, but I shall be glad for both the lads to gain experience, and I hope they will return in good health.'A little later Mr. Page told Charlie and Fred that he had decided to allow them to go to China, an announcement which was received with great delight. The next day he went to the shipping agent's, and finding that a boat would start from Liverpool to Hong-kong in twelve days' time, booked saloon passages for Fred, Charlie, and Ping Wang.'Nonsense,' Mr. Page answered. 'You have been a good friend to my boy and have had a rough time since you have been in England. If you carry away a better impression of our country than you would otherwise have done, I shall consider myself repaid for what I have been able to do for you.' Happiest of little Londoners are those who are so fortunate as to live near enough to the Regent's Park for it to form their daily playground. To them the wooded shores of the winding lake, with its three long arms crossed by bridges that rock delightfully, must seem like a little world, with mountains, bays, capes, forests, and many more wonderful things, just as in the great world itself. It is filled with so many living things that dwell round the banks of the lake--the stately swans, the many varieties of the duck family that swim and fly and chase each other all day long, the gentle moorhens gliding in and out of the rushes, and the mother vole or water-rat nibbling a juicy bit of grass in the sunshine, or swimming to cover with her babies on her back; and now and again the peace of this little world is rudely broken by the distant roar of a real lion or the shriek of a hungry hyena, which frightens all the smaller animals into silence.Perhaps no greater benefit ever befell the good folk of London town than when, early in the nineteenth century, it occurred to the authorities to turn the old Royal Park of St. Mary-le-bone into a real people's park. A great many plans were suggested for laying out the ground. One very ornamental scheme was probably rejected because of its expense; in it a fine church was to form a central point, with avenues running from it like spokes of a wheel. The design which was accepted and carried out consists of four oval drives lying like rings inside one another; in the centre of the inside one are the Royal Botanical Gardens. Rare and wonderful treasures of vegetable life are kept there--flowering plants and shrubs, palms, ferns, mosses, water-plants, and trees from many lands, each the object of deep thought and care. From time to time grand floral ftes are held in the gardens, and often on summer evenings Shakespeare's plays are acted in the open air.The northern side of the park is chiefly given up to the Zoological Gardens; and, indeed, to the world at large, apart from Londoners, Regent's Park often means nothing but 'the Zoo.' Probably it is safe to say that no other park in the world annually attracts so many visitors.The collection at the Zoological Gardens was begun in 1828, and amongst the first arrivals were the lions from the Tower, for, from ancient days, lions and bears kept the old royal fortress lively. Great sums of money have been spent in securing fine specimens, and now Britons have the satisfaction of knowing that our Zoo is second to none. Amongst recent arrivals at the gardens were two young gorillas from Western Africa, who reached the Zoo in apparent health, but, as has happened on former occasions, after a few weeks the poor things sickened and died. Whether they suffer from the effects of the voyage, or whether the shock of their capture is too great for them, the fact remains that gorillas seem unable to endure the altered conditions of life which most of the other members of the great ape family can put up with.But, with all the attractions of the Zoo, it would not do to be dependent on it for amusement, for even on Monday, 'the people's day,' it costs sixpence, and many of the park's most frequent visitors find pennies hard to come by. Pleasure has to be sought and found on the various recreation grounds, and, in fine weather, cricket and other games are usually in full swing.

A very favourite walk with many visitors is to Primrose Hill, north-west of the Zoo, which rises two hundred and nineteen feet above sea-level, where the air is usually clear and bright, whilst the view over London is very fine. The hill is the property of Eton College, and is separated from the Zoo by the Regent's Canal, as well as by the Albert Road. Beneath the slope is a fine gymnasium, which still further adds to the attractions of the park, and many fine terraces of houses line the outer circles.Late in 1904, when the time came to forward the winter outfits for their soldiers fighting in Manchuria, amongst the wadded overcoats and thick blankets were some hundreds of thousands of ear-protectors made out of rats' skins.Even the military authorities were surprised by these, and wondered where the Government could have found so many rats as to be able to supply their soldiers with such soft and comfortable coverings for their ears.It seems that two years ago plague was raging along the China coast, and, to keep the disease out of Japan, the quarantine authorities made war against the rats. In all the seaports and larger cities rewards were offered for each rat brought; small boys found this a delightful way of earning money, and the competition at once became very keen.Every rat was duly registered, and the place where it was caught noted, and if any suspicious germs were found, the building from which the rat came was raided, all the rats in it hunted down, and the place disinfected. So the plague was kept out of Japan. None of my early recollections of our pretty little home in England is so clear as that of the old grandfather's clock that stood in the hall. I remember that my mother and father were very fond of it, and when my brother and I once grumbled, saying, 'That old clock is always slow,' my mother reproved us with the words: 'Oh, children, you must not say that, for the fact that it often goes slow when the big hand is going up towards the hour was the very thing that once saved your great-grandfather's life.'That was the curious thing about the clock. Every now and then, for some reason, the minute-hand seemed to work loose, soon after the half-hour, and, before it reached the three-quarters, it lost five minutes. It might manage to go a whole day without doing this; but sooner or later it always happened, so that the clock could not be relied upon for time.'You know, children, that we have not always lived in England; my ancestors were French, and lived at Chteau Roquefort, in the province of La Vende. When the great insurrection broke out in the year 1792, my grandfather, Philippe de Roquefort, was one of the leading insurgents against the Republic. For a time the insurrection was successful, and the Republican generals were driven across the Loire. But at last there came a time when Philippe de Roquefort saw that to resist any longer was hopeless, and, as he had a wife and a little son, he resolved that, for their sakes, it was prudent to flee to England.'They had abandoned Roquefort itself three days before, but the evening before their leaving France, Philippe was obliged to ride over to the chteau (five miles or so from the little town where he and his family, with about a dozen trusty followers, had taken refuge) to fetch some important papers.'The whole place had a forsaken air as Philippe entered the hall he knew so well, where all his happy boyhood had been spent; but one familiar object caught his eye--the old clock, which had been too cumbersome to take with them in their flight, and which was still ticking in its accustomed manner. Philippe secured his papers, and was just leaving the chteau, taking a last fond look at his home, when a heavy hand pulled him backwards, and, before he could reach his sword, he was bound hand and foot.'Philippe saw that he had been captured by five rough Republicans, who dragged him into the middle of the hall and then sat round him, consulting as to his fate. At last they decided that, at a quarter to six by the old clock, he should be shot. They had some time to wait before going back to their camp.'Philippe gave himself up for lost. The ruffians soon began to jeer at him, and asked if he had any messages for his friends. Then my grandfather lost all his patience, and throwing aside all prudence, cried: "Yes, you villains, if I had my faithful followers here, they would soon make an end of you."'"Yes," he said, "Monsieur shall have his way"--and, looking up at the clock, he continued: "It is now five o'clock; Pierre, the peasant's son, who lives yonder, shall ride with a message to these devoted followers. Monsieur shall be shot at a quarter to six; but he can write and tell his friends to be here at ten minutes to the hour; they will come and find Monsieur--five minutes too late. We can get away easily enough before they arrive."

column25: and Ping Wang their trip to China.'Certainly it would
column26: ' Williams declared. 'Active service is the best thing that a man in the navy can desire
column27: but I am afraid that there is no chance of my getting to South Africa. At any rate
column28: I shall go on hoping for foreign service of some sort.'

column1: 'If he has an opportunity
column2: ' Fred declared
column3: after Lieutenant Williams had departed
column4: 'he will make the most of it
column5: I am sure. He is just the kind of man to do something big
column6: and then laugh and pretend that it was a very easy thing to do. I wish that he was coming with us. However
column7: it's no good wishing. I'm going to have a good long sleep for my last night in the old home. Good night
column8: all.'Charlie and Ping Wang followed Fred's example and went to bed as quickly as possible. They awoke early
column9: and later in the day reached Liverpool and went aboard the _Twilight_
column10: which was to be their home for five or six weeks.The _Twilight_ was a cargo boat which had accommodation for twenty saloon passengers
column11: but she rarely carried that number
column12: as
column13: her speed being but ten knots an hour
column14: most people proceeding to China travelled by a faster and
column15: consequently
column16: more expensive steamer.Fred and Charlie looked at each other in amazement. They had fully expected that there would be all sorts of amusements to break the monotony of their long voyage
column17: and their disappointment was great. However
column18: when they found that in consequence of their being the only passengers each might have a cabin to himself
column19: their discontent quickly passed away. And when they got well out to sea they had plenty of amusements
column20: for the captain had the shuffle-board
column21: deck quoits
column22: and other games brought out
column23: and with the second officer and chief engineer played the passengers.When the three passengers wearied of deck games
column24: they sat on the poop reading some of the books which they had borrowed from the ship's library. Fred sometimes brought out his medical books
column25: but he obtained more practical than theoretical knowledge that voyage
column26: for the ship's doctor--a young fellow who had been recently qualified and was taking a sea voyage
column27: and small pay in return for his medical services--was completely prostrated by sea-sickness
column28: and utterly useless as a doctor. Fred attended to him
column29: doctored such of the crew as needed it
column30: and successfully set a stoker's dislocated forefinger. The sailors in our submarines have found out a simple device to protect their lives whilst on their 'under-sea' trips. Every submarine that goes to sea takes out a couple of mice. If one of these mice shows symptoms of distress
column31: it is a sure sign that the time for coming to the surface has arrived
column32: and that the air of the closed box needs replenishing from the fresh air. Little flower
column33: in meadow bright
column34: With thy raiment sweet and white
column35: Knowest thou who set thee there
column36: Gave to thee a dress so fair
column37: Caused thee from the ground to spring
column38: Such a sweet and tender thing
column39: Sent the rain and sent the sun
column40: Sent the stars when day is done? Little flower
column41: dost thou not know It was God Who made thee grow
column42: Gave to thee thy lovely dress
column43: Such as kings can ne'er possess; Set thee in thy little bed
column44: Gave thee petals
column45: white and red; Sent for thee the dewdrop bright
column46: Shuts thy blossom up at night? Little bird
column47: high in the air
column48: Flying here and everywhere
column49: Dost thou know who made thy wing
column50: Gave thee thy sweet song to sing; Brought thee o'er the ocean track
column51: Guided thee in safety back
column52: Caused thee with the spring to come To thy green and shady home? Little bird
column53: God made thy wing
column54: Gave thee all thy songs to sing; Set thee in the woods and trees
column55: Fanned thy nest with gentle breeze. He it was who brought thee home
column56: Safe across the ocean's foam
column57: To the meadows green and bright
column58: Gave thee songs of sweet delight. A certain Khan of Tartary
column59: making a journey with his nobles
column60: was met by a dervish
column61: who cried with a loud voice: 'If any one will give me a piece of gold I will give him a piece of advice.' The Khan ordered the sum to be given him
column62: upon which the dervish said
column63: 'Begin nothing of which thou hast not well considered the end.'The courtiers
column64: upon hearing his plain sentence
column65: smiled
column66: and said with a sneer
column67: 'The dervish is well paid for his maxim.' But the king was so well satisfied with the answer
column68: that he ordered it to be written in golden letters in several places of his palace
column69: and engraved on all his plate.Not long after
column70: the king's surgeon was bribed to kill him with a poisoned lancet. One day
column71: when the king needed bleeding
column72: and the fatal lancet was ready
column73: the surgeon read on the bowl which was close by: 'Begin nothing of which thou hast not well considered the end.' He started
column74: and let the lancet fall out of his hand. The king observed his confusion
column75: and inquired the reason. The surgeon fell prostrate
column76: and confessed the whole affair. The Khan
column78: told them: 'That counsel could not be too much valued which had saved the life of your king.'

column1: Bohemia is a land of rugged mountains and towering pine-forests
column2: with other beauties of its own. Not many years ago it was
column3: to most English people
column4: an unknown land; but in these days
column5: when travelling is so easy and rapid
column6: year by year an ever-increasing number of our countrymen find their way to this beautiful country in search of health and pleasure. You have only to cross the strip of silver sea that rolls between our little island and sunny France or misty Holland
column7: and you may then rush on
column8: borne by the fastest of express trains
column9: over the level plains that greet you on landing
column10: on through the beautiful Rhineland and the quaint old towns of Bavaria
column11: till at length you find yourself in this land of enchantment.Here
column12: surrounded by the mighty forests
column13: and shut in by the mountains
column14: stands the town of Marienbad. Not very long ago it was a lonely village
column15: inhabited during the summer months by peasants tending their flocks and herds on the pasture of the table-land. In winter it was almost deserted
column16: given over to the wild storms that swept the mountain slopes and to the wolves and bears that roamed through the forests.Gradually the wonderful qualities of its mineral springs became known
column17: and now a crowd of fashionable folk pour into it during the summer
column18: and in every direction trees are being cut down to make way for villas
column19: and buildings of all kinds
column20: which are springing up like mushrooms.English boys and girls would
column21: perhaps
column22: not care to go for a ride in the Bohemian waggons
column23: as they are so fond of doing in ours during harvest-time. These waggons are made of a few long
column24: wide planks
column25: nailed together so as to form a kind of huge trough
column26: and strengthened on the outside by cross-pieces of wood. This is placed upon the framework with which the wheels are connected
column27: and then roughly fastened to it. These clumsy vehicles are drawn over the rough mountain roads by teams of patient oxen. On _fte_ days the cattle look very gay
column28: for then they are decked out with ribbons of many colours.The women of Bohemia work very hard indeed; they help their husbands in all kinds of work. Among other occupations they act as bricklayers' labourers. They run up and down the tall ladders with heavy loads of bricks or mortar
column29: chattering gaily all the while as if life were one long holiday.The houses are built in quite a different way from ours. First of all a complete skeleton house is set up
column30: made of wood
column31: and
column32: when this is finished
column33: the spaces between the wooden structure are filled in with bricks and mortar. Before the roof is put on
column34: a large green bush is hoisted up as far as the eaves
column35: and there tied to the scaffolding poles. This is supposed to drive away the pixies or wicked fairies
column36: and no one would dare to put the roof on without the protection of the green bush.The women also do the work of journeymen bakers. The loaves are of the long kind
column37: sometimes jokingly called 'half-yards of bread.' These are carried on the backs of the women. They look very droll with their huge burdens
column38: the loaves poking out in all directions above their shoulders
column39: making a kind of background to their stooping figures.Most of the people who visit Bohemia in order to take the mineral waters are very stout. They drink them to make themselves thinner
column40: and the difference in their appearance when they arrive and when they leave is very great. They have sometimes to take mud baths
column41: and it is very amusing to watch them going and returning from these. It does not seem to be a very pleasant way of spending a fine summer morning
column42: but they appear to enjoy it all the same. Now see! his face is All aglow; He's tied both laces In a bow; He's combed his hair
column43: He's brushed his suit-- There's not a speck On either boot; His collar now Is new and clean-- A neater boy I've never seen.'I don't see the good of it myself
column44: ' said Harold
column45: rather scornfully
column46: but Frank only laughed good-temperedly
column47: and began to swing himself on a branch of the tree for change of exercise. If there was one thing he hated more than another
column48: it was sitting still for too long a time.

column1: The same evening the boys were on the platform of the little village station
column2: watching some trucks being shunted from the main line on to a siding. Suddenly there was a loud cry from one of the men engaged in the work as a heavy truck got off the rails
column3: turned over
column4: and dragged another with it. No one was seriously hurt
column5: but the station-master
column6: who was soon on the scene of the accident
column7: turned pale as he saw the obstruction on the line.'Stop the down express!' he shouted. But the signal-box was a quarter of a mile away
column8: and precious minutes would have passed before he could be near enough for his voice to reach the signal-man. By that time it might be too late to stop the express.Then
column9: like an arrow
column10: a nimble little figure flew past him. It was Frank
column11: his running powers put to some practical use at last. The station-master followed as quickly as he could. But when at last he came up breathless
column12: he found that Frank had already done his work
column13: and the signal was against the train.But it was only a few yards off the overturned trucks that the express was finally brought to a standstill. The few seconds gained by Frank's speed had saved her. Nothing could have prevented a terrible accident if the signal had not caused the train to slow down just in time.'So your running was some good after all
column14: ' Harold said
column15: and he no longer laughed at his small brother's hobby
column16: but learned to admire the nimbleness of body which
column17: with his ready wit
column18: made him of so much use in an emergency. Most of us have a vague idea that what we call the 'ear' is only partly concerned with the work of hearing; but only a few know exactly what a complicated organ the ear
column19: as a whole
column20: really is. The external 'ear' only serves as an aid to the collection of sounds
column21: and the real work of hearing is performed by a delicate organ inside the head. Seals
column22: moles
column23: whales
column24: and porpoises
column25: birds
column26: reptiles
column27: and fishes have no visible ear; yet we know that they are not deaf
column28: though in many the hearing must be dull. In all these creatures the sense of hearing lies inside the head.But the ears of insects must be looked for in strange places indeed
column29: and
column30: when found
column31: they seem to bear no sort of likeness to what most of us call ears. They may be on the antenn
column32: on the trunk
column33: or on the legs! In the grasshopper
column34: for example (fig. 1)
column35: the ear is placed on the abdomen
column36: just above the base of the great hind-leg
column37: so that this leg must be pulled down before the ear can be seen. When this has been done
column38: there will be found an oval drumhead-like spot (figs. 2 and 3); this is the outer surface of the ear. If you had sufficient skill to take away this part of the body
column39: so as to show the inside of this drum
column40: you would find two horn-like stalks
column41: to each of which is fastened a small and very delicate flask
column42: with a long neck. This is filled with a clear fluid
column43: and corresponds to a similar structure within our own ears.In a little gnat-like insect known as Corethra
column44: common in England during the summer months
column45: the 'ear' takes the form of delicate hairs growing out from the body on a stem
column46: like the teeth of a comb; the base of what corresponds to the back of the comb is connected with a delicate nerve
column47: and this
column48: as in the case of the similar nerve in the grasshopper and locust
column49: makes hearing possible.Only in some ants and bees
column50: and in some mosquitoes
column51: is the organ of hearing placed on the head. We say _on_
column52: rather than _in_
column53: the head
column54: because it is formed by a modification of part of the antenn. A German naturalist
column55: named Mayer
column56: performed an experiment to prove that the hairs on these antenn can be made to vibrate by means of a tuning-fork. Only those hairs which have to do with the production of sound answered to the notes of the tuning-fork
column57: and these vibrated at the rate of five hundred and twelve vibrations per second. Other hairs vibrated to other notes
column58: which were those of the middle octave of the piano and the next above it. Mayer also found that certain of these vibrations corresponded with the notes produced by the 'song' of the female mosquito. Consequently
column59: when she begins to 'sing
column60: ' her tune
column61: like the tuning-fork
column62: sets in motion those hairs on the antenn of the male which are tuned to these vibrations. Having once found
column63: by the movement of his antenn
column64: much as a horse moves his ears
column65: from which direction the sound is coming
column66: the male is able to fly at once to his mate. From the accuracy of this flight
column67: Professor Mayer believes that the perception of sound in these little creatures is more highly developed than in any other class of animals.

column1: The sense of smell in insects lies mainly in those wonderful organs
column2: the antenn or 'horns.' Scents of various kinds are perceived either through pits
column3: or through peg- or spike-like teeth filled with fluid. The leaf-like plates of the antenn of the cockchafer (fig. 5) have these pits very highly developed. On the outer surface of the first 'antennal' leaf
column4: as also on the edges of the other leaves
column5: only scattered bristles are seen; but on the inner surface of the first and seventh leaves
column6: and on both surfaces of all the other leaves
column7: there are close rows of shallow
column8: irregularly shaped hollows. Their number is enormous--in the males as many as thirty-nine thousand
column9: and
column10: in the female
column11: thirty-five thousand on each antenna. As some of the scent-laden air reaches the surface of these pits
column12: it causes the nerves of smell to be roused
column13: and so guides the beetle to its mate
column14: or to its food
column15: according to the nature of the smell. These pits are so tiny that they cannot be shown on the antennal leaves of the cockchafer shown in fig. 5
column16: but they are there. On fig. 6 a highly magnified section of one of these 'leaves' of the antenna is shown: 'P' is the pit
column17: 'N' is the nerve
column18: and 'S. C.' the sense-bulb of the nerve in which it terminates--the point at which the smell is perceived. Fourteen days after leaving Liverpool the _Twilight_ arrived at Port Said
column19: and Fred
column20: Charlie
column21: and Ping Wang at once went ashore. The Pages thoroughly enjoyed their first glimpse of the East
column22: for Ping Wang
column23: knowing the place
column24: took care that they should see everything worth seeing. After sitting for a time in a big _caf_ which was crowded with men of almost every European nation
column25: they wandered through the shop district
column26: and out into the Arab portion of the town.After they had looked at the sights for some little time
column27: Ping Wang suggested that they should have a donkey ride. They had noticed the large
column28: handsome donkeys soon after they landed
column29: but as the passengers from a big P. & O. vessel had come ashore just before they arrived
column30: all the animals were engaged. But when they returned to the busy part of the town they found three donkeys on hire
column31: and the donkey 'boys
column32: ' two of whom were elderly men
column33: at once shouted out the names of their animals.A Port Said donkey sometimes has its name changed three or four times in a year
column34: in consequence of its proprietor's desire that it shall always bear one which is just then popular with Englishmen. You may ride on 'W. G. Grace' in June
column35: and on returning to Port Said in December will discover that the same animal is now called 'Mr. Chamberlain
column36: ' or 'Lord Charles Beresford.' The donkeys which Fred
column37: Charlie
column38: and Ping Wang found on hire were named respectively 'Lord Roberts
column39: ' 'General Buller
column40: ' and 'Krger.''Let us have a race
column41: ' Charlie suggested
column42: when they were getting clear of the crowded narrow streets
column43: and immediately all three urged on their donkeys; but
column44: before they had gone many yards
column45: 'Krger' began to leave his companions behind.'This will never do
column46: ' Charlie declared
column47: and touched up 'Lord Roberts' with his stick. Fred tried to hurry up 'General Buller.' Neither of the animals
column48: however
column49: appeared to be at all anxious to exert themselves
column50: and they would have lost the race had not the donkey-man
column51: remembering that his English patrons always seemed pleased when 'Krger' was last
column52: caught hold of 'Krger's' tail with both hands
column53: and
column54: throwing back his head
column55: pulled as if he were engaged in a tug of war. 'Krger
column56: ' not liking this strain upon his tail
column57: slackened speed and stopped. 'Lord Roberts' and 'General Buller
column58: ' evidently fearing that if they continued running they would be treated in the same way as 'Krger' had been
column59: stopped with such suddenness that Fred was shot over his animal's head into the road
column60: and Charlie only just escaped a similar fate by throwing his arms round his Jenny's neck.Charlie and Ping Wang whipped up their donkeys
column61: but no sooner had they started than Fred's animal
column62: in spite of its rider's efforts to restrain it
column63: bolted after them
column64: and
column65: overtaking them
column66: ran a dead heat with 'Lord Roberts.' 'Krger' was last.

column1: When
column2: after a little further exploration of the town
column3: they went back to the _Twilight_
column4: they were thoroughly delighted to find that she had finished coaling
column5: and that nearly all traces of that unpleasant job had been removed.They went down to dinner at once
column6: and when they came on deck again they were in the Suez Canal. Fred and Charlie found plenty to interest them in the Canal. They saw several thin brown pariah dogs wandering about the desert in search of food
column7: and once a dead camel came floating by them. Towards evening the _Twilight_ had to anchor for a time
column8: and the three passengers
column9: with the captain's permission
column10: went ashore and gathered flowers and shells to send home.In the Red Sea there was still more to see. All day long the seagulls--brown with white breasts--hovered around the _Twilight_. Many other birds came and rested on the ship for hours
column11: and
column12: as the weather was intensely hot
column13: Charlie
column14: Fred
column15: and Ping Wang found it very entertaining to sit quietly in their long chairs and watch their pretty little feathered visitors.Three days after leaving Suez they saw
column16: for the first time
column17: the Southern Cross
column18: and
column19: on the following morning
column20: they steamed into what
column21: at first sight
column22: Fred and Charlie thought was land
column23: but was simply a wide streak of floating sand which had been blown out to sea during a sand-storm.At night they were now permitted to sleep on deck--a boon which all three appreciated highly. They took their blankets and pillows on to the poop
column24: and slept with greater comfort than they had experienced for many days
column25: though one night they were caught in a heavy thunder-shower.While they were looking at a heap of dead fish
column26: the captain shouted to them to come over to the starboard side; and on doing so they beheld a shoal of small fish being chased by big ones. To escape their pursuers the small fish jumped out of the water
column27: and were instantly seized by the gulls
column28: a flock of which were hovering around. The gulls had a splendid feast
column29: several hundred of small fish being eaten by them before the _Twilight_ steamed away from the shoal.'Oh
column30: no! Chinamen are never quite bald--at least
column31: I have never met any who are--and the pigtail is fixed to what hair they have. My reason for advising you not to have your hair cut in Port Said was that I wanted you to have long hair by the time we reached Hongkong. I think that it is already long enough for pigtails to be attached.'Charlie was delighted at the prospect of having to don Chinese attire
column32: but Fred was far from pleased. He had provided himself with an excellent khaki campaigning suit
column33: and did not at all like the idea of its lying idle. However
column34: after some further conversation
column35: Ping Wang succeeded in convincing him that
column36: for the success of their plans for recovering the idol
column37: it was necessary that he and Charlie should pass themselves off as Chinese.Ping Wang lent his chop-sticks willingly
column38: and having obtained some boiled rice from the cook
column39: Charlie practised getting it into his mouth. It was an easier task than he had imagined
column40: and when he had become proficient
column41: he passed the chop-sticks on to Fred
column42: who at once set to work to become as accomplished as his brother. Long before they arrived at Hongkong
column43: Fred and Charlie found it as easy to eat with chop-sticks as with a knife and fork. Two men once stopped at a French inn
column44: and gave in charge of the landlady
column45: who was a widow
column46: a bag of money
column47: telling her to give it up to neither of them unless they were both together. A little while afterwards one of the men came alone and asked the landlady to give up the money under the pretence that his companion had to make an important payment immediately. The widow had paid little attention to what had been said to her before
column48: and now
column49: forgetting all about it
column50: gave up the bag. The rogue disappeared with it so quickly that the landlady asked herself if she had not made a mistake.The next day the other man turned up
column51: and made the same request as his comrade had done the previous day
column52: and when the widow told him what had happened
column53: he went into a passion
column54: and summoned her for the loss of his money.Some one who heard of the poor woman's plight advised her to say that she was ready to bring forth the money on the original terms. She asked the plaintiff to produce his comrade. The argument was found plausible by the court
column55: and as the thief took care not to come back
column56: his comrade had to give up his claim.

column1: Many instances of curious animal friendships have been recorded
column2: but not many are stranger than that which a correspondent of the _Field_ relates of a kitten and a peacock in his own grounds. The kitten was a half-wild one
column3: living in the shrubberies near the house. All its brothers and sisters had been destroyed or taken away
column4: and the kitten must have felt very lonely when there were none of its own kind to play with. Being very young and playful
column5: it felt that it must have a friend and playmate of some kind
column6: and it looked round to find one. There was a handsome peacock in the grounds
column7: and pussy admired him very much
column8: and thought she would like to play with him. So she tried to form an acquaintance
column9: and
column10: as the peacock was not half so vain as he looked
column11: she succeeded very well. They were soon so friendly that pussy could rub against him and box his ears with impunity; she even tried to scramble upon his back. He took all her play in good part
column12: and seemed to enjoy it quite as much as she did. Perhaps he was flattered by pussy's admiration
column13: or perhaps he felt a true friendship for his strange companion. Whichever it was
column14: he always looked out for his little playmate
column15: and was evidently pleased to see her. We have all seen instances of the affection and care which most animals give to their helpless or nearly helpless offspring. The cat spends nearly all her day coiled up in some quiet
column16: cosy corner with her family of kittens
column17: and when she leaves them for a few minutes
column18: to stretch her limbs and seek some refreshment for herself
column19: the least squeak of one of her children will bring her back to its side. The hen struts about the farmyard surrounded by her chickens
column20: and at the least appearance of danger the brood runs for shelter under her wings. When the lamb in the field strays from its mother's side she is soon alarmed
column21: and shows her fear by her anxious bleating
column22: which does not cease until the lamb returns to her. And thus it is with nearly every animal
column23: tame or wild. Each gives proofs
column24: if we could only see and understand them
column25: of a wonderful and beautiful love for her young.This motherly care is not quite like the ordinary friendship which one animal may have for another. A cat and a dog may be good friends all their lives. But
column26: though the cat loves her kittens before all things while they are young and weak
column27: later on
column28: when they are sufficiently grown in size and strength to take good care of themselves
column29: her affection gradually dies away
column30: and she becomes indifferent to their wants. Sometimes she will even drive them away from her.Another feature of this parental love is what might almost be called its unthinking strength. The mother animal feels her affections so strong that she cannot restrain them
column31: and she often bestows them upon the strangest animals
column32: along with her own young ones
column33: or when she has been deprived of her own offspring. A hen will hatch ducks' eggs
column34: and take the same care of the ducklings which she would have taken of her own chickens. I have heard of a hen taking charge of three young ferrets for a fortnight. They were placed in her nest because their own mother had died
column35: and she took to them at once
column36: and nestled down over them just as if they had been chickens. They were too helpless to follow her about
column37: as chickens would have done
column38: and she had to sit with them almost the whole time. She combed out their hair with her bill
column39: just as she would have preened the feathers of chickens. The ferrets were fed by their owner
column40: and they were taken away from the nest before they were old enough to do the hen any harm.An even stranger instance of this misplaced affection on the part of a parent has been seen at a railway station recently
column41: according to the newspapers. A cat in the goods shed had three kittens
column42: which she was bringing up in the usual way. Soon after the kittens were born
column43: some of the railwaymen found a young jackdaw
column44: and put it with them. The cat made no objection
column45: but received the bird kindly
column46: and gave just as much care to it as to the kittens. The workmen fed the bird
column47: while the cat took every other care of it
column48: and even washed it
column49: in its turn
column50: with the kittens. The rearing was quite successful
column51: and the bird grew up strong and healthy.

column1: On Coronation Day (August 9th
column3: a number of balloons filled with natural gas were sent off from Heathfield
column4: near Tunbridge Wells. One of these balloons was picked up on August 10th at Ulm
column5: in Germany
column6: having travelled the six hundred miles in less than twenty-four hours.Notice of this fact was sent in German by the finder on a post-card
column7: but he evidently did not understand English
column8: for he copied the wording on the little medal fastened to the balloon: '_Natural gas carried me from Heathfield
column9: Sussex._'1. Behead weak
column10: and leave a bar. 2. Behead kept too long
column11: and leave an interesting narrative. 3. Behead a firm hard animal substance
column12: and leave a single number. 4. Behead to agitate
column13: and leave a sea-fish. 5. Behead sudden terror
column14: and leave what we should all do. 6. Behead to melt
column15: and leave a berry. About the year 1845
column16: a 'Ragged School
column17: ' as it was called
column18: was started in a very poor quarter of London
column19: but so turbulent and noisy were the boys that at last the teachers found themselves obliged to engage the services of a policeman to keep order.This policeman was himself a 'bit of a scholar
column20: ' and had also a love of boys
column21: and he suggested that if he took a class in the school it might be the best way of maintaining order amongst the unruly crew.The experiment was tried
column22: and proved a great success. The worst and noisiest boys were drafted into the policeman's class
column23: and he somehow tamed them all. More than that
column24: his class was so popular that all the boys wanted to belong to it
column25: and they gave their constable the title of 'King of the Peelers.' It was early one morning when the _Twilight_ arrived at Hongkong
column26: and the Pages and Ping Wang at once went ashore in a _sampan_
column27: or native boat
column28: to present a letter of introduction which they had brought from England.Although it was only half-past six when they arrived at the Hongkong merchant's office
column29: they found the manager
column30: to whom their letter was addressed
column31: already hard at work. He had received
column32: some days before
column33: from the head of the firm in London
column34: notification of the Pages being on their way to Hongkong
column35: and greeted them very cordially.'I had hoped
column36: ' he said

Rings, from a time very far back, have been worn as ornaments on the hands, and given by people to each other as tokens of affection or as a sign of power. The oldest rings known were very large and cumbrous, and they were adorned with stones, sometimes flattened to make seals on wax or clay. The gemmal ring, as it is called, is an old kind, probably several centuries old, and rings of this sort are not made now. From what we know about them, it would appear the first ones were of French work, that nation being long remarkable for skill in contriving curious jewellery. Some may have been made in Italy, and even in our own land rings have been dug up from the earth, where they were hidden away with other valuables, or perhaps occasionally buried with those who had worn them.A gemmal ring has a double row of hoops, locked within each other like the links of a chain. One edge of each ring is flat, so that when one is slipped over the other, the gemmal looks like a single ring. While opened out, two persons can put a finger into the hoops, and this fact gives the origin of the old name applied to them, though it has somehow got a little altered. 'Geminal' was the proper spelling, coming from the Latin _geminus_ (a twin), because such a ring is twin or double. Of course, owing to its form, a gemmal ring was valued as a love token; and at one period it was often used as an engagement ring, or even as a marriage ring. It is supposed that some gemmals, which have one ring gold and the other silver, were made for wedding rings, the gold being for the wife and the silver for the husband. There are gemmals still existing which are adorned with precious stones, and some have singular devices on their sides. One found at Horsleydown, in Surrey, had on each of the two parts of the ring a hand, draped, and holding half a heart; when the ring was closed, the hands appeared joined, holding a whole heart between them. Other rings had mottoes in French or English.

A race which invaded and conquered England. A Dane once brought to his country a beautiful he-ass from Andalusia, and the animal was exhibited as a curiosity in all the towns. An innkeeper of a place between Hamburg and Lubeck took it for a sign; he had it painted, and hung the sign at the door of his inn, with the inscription, 'The Ass of Denmark;' and the good accommodation of the inn rendered it famous.Many years after, the Prince of Denmark, in passing by that place, took lodging there. The honour was so highly appreciated by the innkeeper that he begged the prince to allow him to take his portrait for a sign, and this was granted him. Another innkeeper immediately bought the well-known sign of the Ass, and by this means attracted to his inn all travellers. The other then perceived his want of foresight; and in order to remedy it, he had written at the foot of the portrait of the Prince of Denmark, '_This is the original Ass._'

column1: A well-known writer, who lives where ferns abound, says that the bracken is the fern of ferns in the British Islands. The shelter of it is a pleasure and a safeguard too, not only to the tall deer and their fawns, but to thousands of quadrupeds and birds, whose home is amid the copses, shady lanes, or moorlands. In sandy wastes, this fern only grows a foot high; along the paths in woods it will attain to six or seven feet, or grow taller still in a lofty hedge, or in a clump of supporting trees. Even in the winter months the ferns have their uses; it is delightful, after walking over some moist lowland, to come upon a hilly ridge of ground, where, amongst the birches and the fragrant firs, the brown ferns grow freely.Grand in its growth, but only to be found in a few places, is the Osmund or Royal Fern, which throws up a tall spike bearing the spores or seeds of the plant. Sometimes, in moist places, the crown of the root is a clump of more than a foot high, from which the stem rises. Of late years, this kingly fern has become still more rare, and happy is the fern-hunter who comes upon a specimen.Who can help admiring the beautiful Lady Fern, which seems to be most at home when growing near a streamlet or pond? It is stately and graceful, with large fronds of clear green, and the tips of its sprays bend like plumes. What is called the Male Fern grows in hedges or banks, and indeed almost anywhere; a handsome cheery-looking plant, though of moderate size. It will even manage to live in a London back-garden, or area, and many cottagers have it amongst the flowers of their small garden plots. Occasionally, by the side of a copse, we may come upon a great bed of the male fern, which frequently keeps green all the winter. Often, about the same spots where the male fern flourishes, the Shield Fern displays its fronds, larger and broader, but fewer in number, and prettily toothed along their edges. Fond of damp hollows or the sides of ditches is the handsome Hart's-tongue Fern, which will also, now and then, choose to grow on a cracked wall, or perhaps down a well.We must not forget the Polypody, which delights to creep amongst the trees and bushes of a lane, and looks very fresh in June, keeping its fronds till some sharp frost brings them off. It took the name of Polypody from its jagged leaves, upon which the seeds or spores appear in bright orange spots. The humble Wall Rue and the Wall Spleenwort grow on walls chiefly, sometimes on rocky banks. The true Maiden-hair Fern is amongst the rarest of our native ferns. What is so commonly grown by gardeners, and used for bouquets and buttonholes, is the Black Maiden-hair, a rather stronger plant. 'I wish,' said the Pansy, 'I had not been planted To catch the full force of the wind from the east; But, somehow, the gardener takes it for granted That that's not a hardship I mind in the least.
