'The pinks and the roses are grandly protected, They're touched but by winds from the south and the west; Yet here, in exposure, I'm always expected To blossom in colours my brightest and best. The sun on my home his warm light seldom squanders, And only when night is beginning to fall; While if through the garden the honey-bee wanders, He never looks twice at my corner at all. 'But light is my heart as the fairest of roses, For yesterday morning, in kindliest tone, I heard some one say, who was gathering posies, "I'm fond of that pansy that blossoms alone." Just think of it! Some one has noticed me growing! I don't want the wind from the south and the west, And, spite of the hurricane bitterly blowing, I'll blossom in colours the brightest and best.' Hetais was a French sailor, a carpenter of the _Ville de Paris_, and he and his ship-mates took part with our soldiers in the siege of Sebastopol in 1854, where Hetais, having shown great gallantry during one of the sorties, was adjudged that coveted decoration, the _mdaille militaire_--a medal that is only given to privates and non-commissioned officers.The presentation of this medal was to be made on a certain evening, and on the morning, as he and his mates were on duty in the trenches, the chief subject of conversation was the honour that had befallen Hetais.'Look here,' he said to his particular chum, 'I have just drawn out all the money owing to me, and I mean you fellows to have a good, hot supper to-night at the canteen, and I foot the bill!' and as he spoke he pulled out a handful of silver from his pocket and showed it with a laugh to his friend.

'All right,' said the man, cautiously lifting his head above the shelter of the trench, so as to see what the Russians were about. 'The "Moscos"' (so the French termed the enemy) 'seem keeping quiet to-day, and we shall be able to enjoy our coffee in peace,' he continued.A fire was lighted, and the water put on to boil in a saucepan, the men all sitting round in eagerness, for it was bitterly cold in the trenches, and a hot cup, or rather tin, of coffee seemed to warm and cheer them better than anything else.Every man held out his mess-tin--but not one drop of coffee was to be drunk by any of them, for at that very moment a bomb from the Russian battery landed in their midst, upsetting the saucepan of coffee and exploding in the midst of the little crowd of men.It seemed as if none could escape! Yet, strange to say--for this is a true story--of all that group, no one was hurt, except the brave Hetais, whose head had been all but blown away by the bursting of the bomb.'Poor fellow! he was a brave man if there ever was one,' said the officer. 'Carry his body back to camp, my lads; he shall be honoured in death, if he has just missed it in life,' for the officer was thinking of the medal and the ceremony of presentation which was to have taken place that evening.The men extemporised a sort of bier out of a litter on which the dead man was lying and their muskets, and thus they reverently carried him back to camp, the relief party presenting arms as the funeral procession passed by them.A few hours later, all the sailors and soldiers who could be spared from the trenches were drawn up in a hollow square outside the camp around the body of Hetais, who, wrapped in his cloak, slept his last calm sleep on the rough litter in which he had been carried from the trenches.The deep silence was at last broken by the loud voice of the commanding officer: 'Present arms!' Then he took off his helmet, and followed by another officer, who carried the medal, he advanced towards the bier, and read out the brief account of the gallant action which had gained Hetais his medal.'A glorious death has ended a noble life,' he said, in a loud, clear voice, which could be heard by all; 'but death, though it has robbed us of a brave comrade, shall not rob him of the honour due to his services. In the name of the General commanding the forces in the East, I confer on our dead comrade the _mdaille militaire_!' It was the visit to Dan Webster which brought it all about; but for the fact that the handle of Charlie's bicycle got badly bent, so that only the village blacksmith could put it right, the most exciting incident which ever befell the boys would probably never have taken place.A serious look came into old Dan's face. 'I'd send my daughter away to the seaside for a change,' he said. 'The doctor tells me it would do her more good than all his medicines. But what's all this,' he asked, 'about twenty pounds reward? I suppose it's some joke of yours, young gentlemen?''It's no joke,' said Charlie; 'at least, Lady Winterton does not think so. She is on a visit to our house, you know; and this morning she discovered that she had lost a valuable necklace. Father was so angry that such a thing should have happened that he at once offered twenty pounds reward for the recovery of the necklace.'The blacksmith then told all he knew, and the boys, as soon as Charlie's bicycle was ready, started off, as they fondly hoped, on the track of the thief. After a good long ride, they suddenly came upon the object of their search. He was leisurely taking photographs on the outskirts of a wood. No horse was visible, so he had evidently been home to breakfast, and had started forth again.The stranger was nearly doubled up with laughter, which he turned away to hide. 'Well, you see,' he replied, as gravely as he could, 'Lady Winterton left it about so temptingly that I really couldn't help it. It's my first offence, though.'

column1: At an electrical exhibition held at Paris in 1881

column7: shaped like a fish's tail

column9: which met under the centre of the gas-bag

column40: and the screw are all suspended from the silk envelope by piano wires

column1: Misadventures of this sort have only increased the keenness with which M. Santos Dumont pursues his studies. The principal triumph he has yet secured was won some three years ago

column1: Sir Frederick Doyle, while watching some wasps eating plums on his trees, knocked one down without killing it. The wasp fell into a large spider's web below. To his surprise a fellow-wasp instantly flew down to the rescue. He poised himself close to the spider's web, whirling his wings till they looked like glittering rainbows, so fast that their shape could not be seen. This was to prevent them from being caught in the sticky web, and all the time he was striking deft and rapid blows at the threads that held his friend fast. At length he cut him out, but the poor rescued insect fell down to die upon the ground. The observer adds: 'I was so much struck with this proof of a heart as well as a brain in the case of wasps that I not only spared the "V.C." wasp who rescued his friend, but also the rest of the troop, and left the plums to their fate.'The weasel, that terrible foe to rabbits and rats, is not famous for good temper, yet a pretty tale is told of one of them. A gentleman was riding home, when his horse trod on a weasel, which was unable to get out of the way in time. The poor little animal's spine seemed to be hurt, and it could not move its hind legs. Presently another weasel came out of the hedge by the roadside, and went up to the injured one. After carefully inspecting it, the second weasel picked up the first and carried it to the side of the road, out of the way of the traffic, where he gently laid it down.Wild elephants seem unable to bear the sight of suffering friends without an attempt to save them, and in particular the wild herds of these noble beasts love and protect their leaders. When pressed by hunters, they place him in the midst and crowd in front of him, eager to save his life at the expense of their own. Professor Romanes gives an instance of a fine 'tusker' which, when badly wounded, was promptly surrounded by his companions. They supported him between their shoulders, and actually succeeded in covering his retreat to the forest.Birds are very generous towards each other in these ways, particularly such as live in communities together. If one rook of a colony gets into trouble, all the rest are worried about him directly. A great mob of rooks, living in trees near the river Irwell, were seen chasing each other playfully on the wing, dancing idly with joy and pleasure at the coming spring, when one of them accidentally knocked against another, and fell into the river below. In an instant a chorus of distress was raised; the birds hovered over their friend, as he struggled in the water, with cries of sorrow and alarm, and seemed to be giving him advice in some fashion of their own. At any rate, urged by their voices, he sprang into the air, and by one strong effort managed to reach a point of rock. The shouts of joy at his safety echoed far and wide.Much tenderness is shown by grown-up birds to helpless orphans in need of their aid. A redbreast was mentioned lately in _Science Gossip_ as doing a deed of kindness towards a young starling one bitterly cold morning. The starling had left the nest, and was sitting frightened and shivering in a cellar, whither it had crept, too weak and hungry to fly. In vain kindly human hands offered it bread; it refused all food, till a little hungry robin came down on his daily visit to the house and spied the baby-bird, sitting on one leg, calling his absent mother. Off he went, and soon came darting back with a worm, which was gratefully accepted. When the beggar-bird had been fed, both flew away. Seagulls have been seen assisting a wounded comrade over the wave, and a crane, seeing one of its fellows shot, placed itself under the sufferer in such a way as to prevent his falling to the ground; then, weighted as he was, he bore him away beyond gun-shot.

column22: and they were on their way to catch the mail-train to town

column24: they were detained beyond time at the bank
column25: in which they both were clerks
column26: and so missed the last train to town from their little branch station. There was just time
column27: however
column28: for them to catch a train on the main line
column29: but to do this they had to take a short cut through Lord Ravensmere's woods
column30: and the thick snow having covered the paths
column31: they lost their way several times
column32: and this
column33: of course
column34: delayed them again.However
column35: the walk was nearly over; the station lamps could be seen twinkling in the valley below
column36: and the young fellows were hurrying on
column37: when they heard a faint cry
column38: 'Help! help!' coming seemingly from the wood alongside.Jack nodded
column39: and then
column40: without another word
column41: the two lads lifted the unconscious youth
column42: and somehow
column43: with interlaced hands to form a seat
column44: they stumbled along that snowy mile to the Castle
column45: supporting the stranger between them as best they could.The old man's gratitude to the young clerks was simply unbounded. He insisted on their spending the night at the Castle
column46: and here
column47: dressed in some of the young heir's suits

column49: later on
column50: in the drawing-room
column51: Lady Ravensmere herself
column52: with tears in her eyes
column53: thanked them warmly for saving her son
column54: and told them they should never forget what they had done.Ping Wang's face beamed. He pulled off his coat and trousers and donned in their place a dirty jacket and a pair of ragged knickerbockers. Then
column55: taking off his 'beehive
column56: ' he wound round his head the yellow scarf of the Boxers.No one penetrated their disguise as they hurried along the streets. One man informed Ping Wang that the three foreigners had been killed. They had taken refuge in a house and the mob had thereupon set light to it. He pointed to the distant flames. Ping Wang was sorry for the men who had been mistaken for them
column57: if they were really in the burnt house
column58: but could not help feeling relieved at the thought that now the mob had wreaked its vengeance it would probably disperse for the night.'When we turn the next corner we shall be facing the gates
column59: ' Ping Wang said after a short walk; and Charlie and Fred heard the news with thankfulness. They were as determined as ever to recover their friend's wealth before quitting China
column60: but they realised that it would be folly to make another attempt to do so while the Boxers were stirring up the people. Their idea was to return to Hongkong and remain there until the anti-foreign feeling had grown less strong.

column1: Ping Wang was the first to reach the corner. To the astonishment of his friends he stopped short
column2: with an exclamation of surprise. Charlie and Fred were at his side in a moment and saw at once the cause of his astonishment--the town gates were closed!The surprise which they showed on seeing that the gates were closed did not cause any comment or notice among the people standing near
column3: for they too had been surprised and annoyed by the same thing. Chin Choo had given the order for the gates to be shut
column4: and the soldiers dared not open them until they received from him a command to that effect.After a time the crowd began to disperse
column5: some of the people wandering off to find lodgings for the night
column6: and others sitting down by the roadside in the hope that
column7: before long
column8: the gates would be thrown open. Among the latter were the Pages and Ping Wang. They found a dark corner
column9: and sat there almost entirely hidden from passers-by. Ping Wang sat in front of his friends
column10: so that if any one did peer into their corner he would see him
column11: and conclude that his companions were Chinamen. A long silence was at last broken by the shouts of an advancing mob.'Don't talk
column12: ' Ping Wang said
column13: and once more they became silent
column14: listening eagerly to distinguish what the mob was shouting. In a few minutes their suspicions were confirmed
column15: for the cry which burst from hundreds of throats was one that there was no need Ping Wang to translate--Charlie and Fred understood only too well what it meant.'Kill the foreigners!' Nearer each moment came the crowd
column16: every man uttering the same cry. Soon it came in sight. At the head of the mob was Chin Choo in his palanquin
column17: wearing the yellow head-cloth of the Boxers.This was welcome news to Charlie and Fred
column18: and remembering that they too were members of the Boxers' Society
column19: they watched the crowd with great interest. Every Boxer wore his yellow head-cloth
column20: and carried a weapon of some sort. A few only had rifles
column21: the remainder being armed with swords
column22: knives
column23: bows and arrows
column24: and sticks.When the Boxers had arrived at the town gates
column25: Chin Choo addressed his followers from his palanquin. He declared that the foreigners had come to the Middle Kingdom for the sole purpose of taking their country
column26: and that
column27: therefore
column28: it was necessary to kill them all at once. If any were permitted to escape
column29: they would return to their own land
column30: and come back with many more. Then he declared that the Boxers would avenge all the cruelties which he said had been enacted by the foreigners
column31: and finished up with the statement that the Boxers could not be wounded. Bullets would glide off their skin without making a scar
column32: and swords
column33: spears
column34: and knives would make no impression.Chin Choo saw that the people had doubts about the truth of his last assertion
column35: and beckoned two of his officers to approach him. He talked with them for a few moments
column36: and then declared
column37: in a loud voice. 'Now you shall see that nothing can harm the men who wear yellow head-cloths.'As he spoke six Boxers advanced
column38: and stood with their backs to the town gates. Then twelve of the soldiers marched forward with their rifles at the trail
column39: and halted about twenty yards in front of them. At the word of command they loaded their rifles and raised them to their shoulders. An instant later they fired a volley at the six Boxers
column40: but
column41: to the astonishment of the onlookers
column42: not one of the men was injured.

column1: The crowd was delighted with this miracle, and the Boxers themselves became wild with joy. They waved their weapons about, and shouted to be led against the enemy at once. Their desire was granted, the gates were thrown open, and the Boxers marched out of the town.They slipped into the road, and joined the tail of the Boxers boldly, brandishing the knives that they had with them in imitation of the Chinamen's actions. Ping Wang shouted as loudly as any man, and shook his fist fiercely at an imaginary enemy.Charlie saw that it would not be a difficult thing to escape from the rabble army, for men straggled away right and left, just as they felt inclined. The officers walked in front, and beyond looking round occasionally to see that the mob was following, kept no further watch on them.Before long Ping Wang halted to rearrange his head-cloth. Charlie and Fred turned, and stood looking at him as if they were waiting for him to finish and march on. Their action was very natural, and the few men who had been marching behind them passed on without a remark.Ping Wang continued to fumble about with his head-cloth until the last of the Boxers were out of sight. Then he said, 'Now's our time,' and quitted the track. The bushes, which grew thickly along the roadside, afforded ample 'cover' if they needed it.'There may be other fellows following him,' he added, 'and a shout from any one of them would bring the mob rushing over here in a moment. The best thing that we can do is to hurry on as quickly as possible.'Ping Wang, however, did not agree; he preferred to keep on running. But he sadly over-rated his running powers, and before they had gone another hundred yards he had to stop and gasp for breath. The pursuer was now approaching them rapidly, so Charlie and Fred grasped their knives and waited for him. He increased his speed, and, as he drew nearer, they saw that he was wearing the yellow head-cloth of the Boxers.'Englisheeman pigtail plenty good,' Number One cook explained, but added the unflattering information that 'Englisheeman no can hide welly much funny nose, welly much funny eyes, welly much funny mouth.'Ping Wang, having recovered his breath, took up the conversation, Charlie and Fred meanwhile keeping a sharp look-out for Boxers. When they had walked quickly about a quarter of a mile, Ping Wang brought his conversation in Chinese to a close.'This man says,' he informed the Pages, 'that he is employed at the mission station for which we are bound. He had been sent up-country by the missionaries on business, and was returning through Kwang-ngan when he saw the anti-foreign placard. He did the same thing as we did--hurried to the gates--but did not reach them until after they were closed. Being hungry, he went back to get some food, and on his way to the shop he met a sleepy Boxer, who had apparently just come from an opium den. Number One said to himself, "I will have that head-cloth," and he took it, giving the Boxer his own hat instead. Then, after a while, he made his way to the gates, arriving there just as the Boxers were marching out. He declares that he knew that both of you were Englishmen the moment he saw you. He kept his eyes on us, and decided to join us.'
Being now about half a mile ahead of the Boxers
column2: the two Englishmen and the two Chinamen made their way back to the track
column3: and
column4: after walking quickly for another hour
column5: arrived at the gates of Su-ching
column6: which they had hoped not to re-enter until they brought with them Ping Wang's treasure. The gates were open
column7: but the soldiers who guarded the entrance to the town had thrown off their usual air of apathy
column8: and were questioning eagerly every man who came from the direction of Kwang-ngan. On seeing four Boxers approaching
column9: they hurried forward to meet them.The noise of the advancing mob reached them as a faint
column10: buzzing sound
column11: but loud enough to convince the soldiers that the Boxers were really coming. They were anxious to ask Ping Wang and his companions more questions
column12: but Ping Wang cut short their questions.'We bear a message
column13: ' he declared
column14: 'and we must deliver it at once. We have run quickly
column15: for we did not carry rifles. But now that we have finished running
column16: give us rifles
column17: in case we meet any foreigners.'To the soldiers this request appeared to be a perfectly reasonable one
column18: and
column19: knowing that the mandarin and other town officials sympathised with the Boxers
column20: they took from the armoury
column21: which was close by
column22: four Snider rifles
column23: and handed them out to Ping Wang
column24: with ammunition.Feeling safe once more
column25: Ping Wang and his friends hurried off in the direction of the mandarin's house; but
column26: as soon as they got out of sight of the soldiers
column27: Number One exclaimed
column28: 'This way welly much more quick
column29: ' and turned up a narrow side-street. The Pages and Ping Wang followed him
column30: and in about three minutes they arrived at the wall of the mission station
column31: which they saw was already placarded with anti-foreign manifestoes. They rang the bell
column32: but some minutes passed
column33: and the gate was not opened. They rang again
column34: loudly
column35: and a minute later they heard Barton inquire
column36: in Chinese
column37: who they were.'That's splendid!' Barton declared
column38: and
column39: although they could not see him
column40: they knew by his voice that their arrival was welcome. 'Wait a moment
column41: ' he continued; 'the gate is barricaded
column42: but I will lower a ladder to you. Here you are!' he called down a minute later
column43: and on looking up they saw him lowering from the top of the wall a long bamboo ladder. When it touched the ground they planted it firmly.'Hurry up!' Barton sang out
column44: and Ping Wang
column45: seeing that Charlie was determined to be the last man up
column46: climbed the ladder. Just as he reached the top
column47: and as Charlie planted his foot on the lowest rung
column48: three men
column49: with knives in their hands
column50: came running up
column51: and Charlie was unaware of his danger; but Fred saw the scoundrels
column52: and slipping a cartridge into the breach of his rifle he took aim
column53: fired
column54: and shot the foremost man. The other two
column55: who had not expected any danger
column56: turned about and fled in terror.'Fred
column57: ' Charlie said
column58: when he had climbed over the wall
column59: 'you saved my life.' Then he turned to Barton. 'I see that you are prepared for the Boxers
column60: ' he said. 'We were afraid that we shouldn't get here in time to warn you of their approach.'Barton sighed. 'I had been hoping
column61: ' he said
column62: 'that the Empress-Dowager would have had the Boxers suppressed before they would be able to reach here. I am afraid
column63: however
column64: that she is secretly encouraging them. It is a great sorrow to my colleagues and myself to find ourselves arming against the people among whom we have lived on friendly terms for some years. However
column65: we must protect our women and children. Since you left us
column66: eight men
column67: five women
column68: and four children have joined us. Some of them have suffered terribly in their flight from the Boxers. Their own mission stations have been destroyed
column69: and many of their fellow-missionaries were murdered. Consequently we may have to fight.'

column1: The other missionaries now joined them
column2: in answer to Barton's summons. The majority were young men
column3: but two were middle-aged
column4: and one a grey-bearded old gentleman. Each had his rifle or revolver
column5: and
column6: although they did not wish to be forced to fight
column7: they had the determined looks of men who knew that their cause was a good one
column8: and were prepared to die in its defence. Their positions at the wall had been settled some hours before
column9: but the arrival of the Pages
column10: Ping Wang
column11: and Number One made a fresh arrangement necessary.'I came to the conclusion
column12: ' Barton said
column13: as he showed Fred the defences
column14: 'that it would be risky to make loopholes in the wall
column15: in case
column16: after a time
column17: we should be unable to place a man at each. Therefore we built those platforms.'The platforms were built at intervals around the wall
column18: each having room for six or seven men. The defenders would have to shoot over the top of the wall
column19: but cover had been provided for them by sandbags fixed securely along the ridge.'Mr. Wilkins
column20: that old gentleman with the grey beard
column21: was a good shot forty years ago; but from the time he first left England
column22: until yesterday
column23: he hadn't touched a rifle. However
column24: he was practising yesterday and to-day
column25: and I have no doubt that he will do well. My other colleagues had never handled a rifle in their lives until this morning
column26: when I gave them a little instruction. I was a member of the Oxford University Corps.''That reminds me that my man got a fine Lee-Metford and a large box of ammunition. They were sold to him at a low price by a boatman who
column27: I suspect
column28: had stolen them at one of the treaty ports. As the rifle was strange to me I held it back until I had time to learn how to fill the magazine. Would you like to have it?'They hurried to the verandah of the house where the Lee-Metford and ammunition lay. Fred picked up the rifle and
column29: after examining it closely
column30: recognised it as the very one which he had used with good effect against the river pirates. He was about to tell Barton of his discovery when loud shouts from the town made known to them that the Boxers had arrived. Fred pulled off his skull-cap
column31: filled it with cartridges
column32: and followed Barton down the steps and up on to the platform
column33: where Charlie
column34: Ping Wang
column35: and Number One were stationed.Cheapside and Ludgate Hill
column36: and many less busy parts of London
column37: ring with such cries for a month before Christmas. All the year round the hawkers are standing patiently on the curbstone with their wonderful penn'orths; but it is at Christmas-time that they do most business. Some children are fortunate enough to be taken by their parents to see the streets at Christmas-time
column38: and sometimes they are allowed to buy some of the pretty things for themselves. But there are many others not so fortunate
column39: who can only look on wistfully
column40: and others again who are not rich enough or
column41: perhaps
column42: too ill even to go and look at the sights. Poor men and women
column43: who cannot really afford even a penny
column44: find in the hawkers' wares the cheapest market
column45: and many a bare
column46: cold home is brightened at Christmas by one or two of the little toys that cost so little
column47: but bring so much happiness.These toys have a wonderful history of their own. Do you know that when you have one of them in your hand
column48: you may be holding what has come thousands of miles over sea and land from the hands of other children in distant countries? Whole families make a living by manufacturing these toys. The material--wood
column49: paper
column50: tinsel
column51: wire
column52: or what not--is given out at the factory
column53: and the worker takes it home. There every one is busy; one cutting out pieces of paper of a given shape
column54: one whittling pieces of wood to fit together
column55: one gumming up the various parts
column56: till the whole toy is finished and added to a growing pile. Nearly every civilised country has such workers--Austria
column57: Germany
column58: France
column59: America

column61: and England; and the toys in the end travel mile after mile in great ships and trains
column62: to be sold in the streets for such a little sum!

column1: The differences in general appearance of the men of various races are most striking. No one could mistake a Chinaman for a North American Indian
column2: or a Negro for a Malay or a Maori. Not only are these men of various races different in outward appearance
column3: but they have also minds of different characters
column4: and seem naturally fitted for different kinds of work.The Chinaman has his own special fields of labour. He is a great trader with the countries near home
column5: and sends out many junks to the East Indies
column6: the Malay Islands
column7: and the South Sea Islands
column8: to collect edible birds' nests
column9: trepang
column10: ornamental woods
column11: pearls
column12: pearl-shells
column13: tortoise-shell
column14: and the skins of birds of paradise. At Singapore
column15: there are hundreds of Chinese shopkeepers
column16: who sell all kinds of miscellaneous articles
column17: such as penknives
column18: cotton thread
column19: writing-paper
column20: gunpowder
column21: and corkscrews
column22: often at a price which would be considered cheap even in England.But it is when the Chinaman settles in some American or Australian town that his special abilities are best seen. He is surrounded and outnumbered by Englishmen and Americans
column23: and is entirely under their government; and yet there are some kinds of work which he can do so well and so cheaply that no European can compete with him. He is an excellent gardener in a small way
column24: and if he can obtain only a very little plot of ground
column25: he will cultivate it so constantly and so carefully that he will be able to maintain himself in comfort with the money which he obtains from the sale of his vegetables and fruits. Many gardens belonging to Chinamen are to be seen on the outskirts of the cities of Australia and New Zealand
column26: and early in the morning the Chinamen hawk their products through the streets.The Chinaman is equally good as a laundryman
column27: and in some cities the Chinese colonists do the whole of the laundry-work. In San Francisco
column28: where there are thousands of Chinese
column29: all the washing is performed by them. They work in the open air
column30: just as the English and Scotch women used to do in their public washing-grounds
column31: standing in the water rubbing and wringing their clothes. They have a curious practice in ironing
column32: of spraying the linen with water through their mouths. They do the work very thoroughly
column33: and at the same time cheaply. A Chinaman will live very comfortably on forty pounds a year
column34: and
column35: as he is an almost incessant worker
column36: he can make sufficient money for his needs by work which is very poorly paid from an Englishman's point of view.Sixteen men to be hanged! It seems quite incredible now
column37: but a hundred years ago the death sentence was given indiscriminately for offences of all sorts
column38: some so trivial as hardly to deserve the name. For instance
column39: the man of sixty
column40: who stood first in the dock
column41: had snatched a ham from a shop-door
column42: to take to some starving children at home; and the country lad of some eighteen years or less
column43: at the other end of the row
column44: had set fire to a rick--it was an accident
column45: it is true
column46: but a quantity of hay had been burnt; the jury found him 'guilty
column47: ' and he was to be hanged with the rest.Poor lad! The judge's words fell on his ear like strokes of a heavy hammer. Surely they could not be meant for him! It was but a few days ago that he had been a happy
column48: careless lad
column49: shouting and laughing over a bonfire in which he and some friends were to roast potatoes. A high wind got up suddenly
column50: and some sparks from their fire were carried to a hay-rick at some little distance
column51: and at once there was a blaze!The other lads slunk away
column52: terrified at the mishap
column53: but this lad
column54: Repton by name
column55: ran up
column56: and tried to stamp out the flames
column57: and so was taken 'red-handed
column58: ' as the angry farmer expressed it
column59: and was there and then lodged in the county jail.And now he was to die! He sat in a corner of the dark underground room
column60: dazed and miserable
column61: whilst the men round him
column62: sentenced like himself
column63: were talking and laughing
column64: and trying by these means to put away the thought of their fate. But Repton was stupefied with anguish
column65: till at last merciful sleep overcame him.The six months which Repton had to pass on the hulks at Sheerness among scenes of wickedness and brutality seemed afterwards like a bad dream
column66: and the lad prayed--oh
column67: so earnestly!--to be kept from the evil which surrounded him. Then came the day when
column68: chained two and two
column69: he and his companions were marched through the streets and shipped on board the _Neptune_
column70: as unseaworthy a craft as ever sailed the ocean
column71: but thought good enough for convicts.

column1: However
column2: the _Neptune_ did not sink; but she took nearly a year to reach her destination
column3: and the convicts
column4: stowed together in the hold
column5: suffered torments from heat and thirst in the tropics. Then small-pox broke out amongst them
column6: and many died; the rest were more like skeletons than living men
column7: when the _Neptune_ at last cast anchor in Botany Bay. Here the men had to work on Government buildings
column8: and at night were locked up in barracks
column9: hardly more roomy or airy than the hold of the old _Neptune_.Most of the convicts did as little work
column10: and gave as much trouble as they dared
column11: and nothing but fear of the overseer kept them from open mutiny. At last
column12: finding the overseer alone one day
column13: and for once unarmed
column14: two or three of the worst convicts set upon him
column15: and would have murdered him
column16: if Repton had not stood by him and helped him till assistance came to overpower the mutineers.The overseer did not forget this act of Repton's
column17: and next time one of the merchants came to the barracks to choose a servant from among the convicts (as was then the custom)
column18: he recommended the lad for the coveted post.Now
column19: indeed
column20: Repton felt almost happy for the first time since his conviction. He was still a convict
column21: it is true
column22: and might be flogged at his master's will
column23: or be sent back to the convict barracks
column24: if he misconducted himself in any way. But
column25: for the moment
column26: he was actually free; he lived in a little shed of his own next the stable
column27: and groomed the horses as a free man; and the relief of no longer being herded with wicked men
column28: day and night
column29: was too great for words.Repton loved horses
column30: too
column31: and took such care of his master's beautiful mare
column32: and the little girl's pony
column33: that there never was any fault to be found with him. As the months went on
column34: he was trusted more and more by both master and mistress
column35: and treated more like a humble friend than a despised convict.Those were lawless days in the Colony; convicts were constantly escaping into the bush
column36: where they lived as they could--often venturing out to rob houses
column37: or attacking and plundering
column38: sometimes even murdering
column39: solitary travellers.Mr. Edmonds
column40: Repton's master
column41: had a house in a somewhat lonely position
column42: half-a-mile or more from any neighbour. He was
column43: however
column44: a man prepared for all emergencies
column45: and
column46: as he was known to be well provided with fire-arms
column47: and not afraid to use them
column48: his house had hitherto been left unmolested.One night
column49: however--a dark
column50: stormy night--Repton was roused by the sound of steel grating against something. Listening more intently
column51: he heard whispers
column52: and finally came to the conclusion that men were trying to force open the house-door. Then it suddenly flashed into Repton's mind that Mr. Edmonds had been summoned hastily away that very evening by a message from a sick friend on the other side of the town
column53: and there was no one in the house but a young nursemaid to protect the mistress and her little girl.Hastily flinging on his clothes
column54: he crept up in the darkness
column55: and
column56: getting behind the two men
column57: who had by this time almost forced the door
column58: he felled one of them to the ground with a well-aimed blow. The other
column59: however
column60: turned savagely on Repton
column61: and the two were soon locked in fight. The burglar was
column62: however
column63: the heavier man of the two
column64: and things were going badly for Repton
column65: whose strength was all but exhausted
column66: when the welcome sound of horses' hoofs was heard
column67: and Mr. Edmonds came galloping up.Then Repton's turn came
column68: and his master shook him by the hand

column70: and thanked him for his bravery
column71: and he was taken indoors
column72: where Mrs. Repton with her own hands brought some soothing lotion to bathe his wounds.Nor was this the end. Mr. Edmonds
column73: who had great influence with the Governor

column75: and set him up in business
column76: and now some of the most respected families in Australia are the descendants of Repton the Convict. 'Here they come
column78: and as he spoke a shouting
column79: wild-looking mob of Chinamen came running down the road to the mission station. Halting about twenty yards away from the mission wall
column80: they waited until their whole force had arrived
column81: contenting themselves in the meanwhile with yelling 'Down with the foreigners!' brandishing their weapons and waving their flags. Soon there were quite three hundred Boxers in the road facing the front of the mission
column82: it being their hope to strike terror by a display of their numbers.At a signal from the leader of the Boxers
column83: about fifty rifles were fired point-blank at the wall. Fred raised his rifle
column85: and the Boxer leader threw up his arms and fell on his face. Fred's shot was taken by the other defenders as the signal to fire

column1: The surprise and terror of the Boxers on discovering that they were not invulnerable formed a sight which none of the defenders will ever forget. Every man was seized with a desire to escape from the foreigners' bullets
column2: and they turned and ran in confusion.'I don't fancy that the Boxers will trouble us again to-night
column3: ' Barton said
column4: a few minutes later
column5: 'for their leaders will have some difficulty after this in convincing them that they cannot be wounded. There is no need for all of us to remain on duty. I dare say you fellows are hungry; come inside.'When he returned
column6: he could not help smiling at what he saw. Ping Wang
column7: wishing to dress like his friends
column8: had put on knickerbockers and a college blazer
column9: down the back of which hung his black
column10: silky pigtail. Charlie was wearing flannel trousers and a khaki tunic
column11: while Fred was attired in a black and somewhat moth-eaten suit
column12: which was too short for him both in arms and legs.He led the way along the verandah
column13: and into a large airy room at the back of the building
column14: where the supper was laid. Four ladies were hard at work making sandbags
column15: a task at which they had been busy since early in the morning. Barton introduced the Pages and Ping Wang to them. In spite of the anxiety which the fact of the mission being besieged caused them
column16: they were cheerful in their conversation
column17: and insisted upon the new-comers making a hearty meal. After supper Charlie
column18: Fred
column19: and Ping Wang returned to their posts
column20: relieving the missionaries
column21: and enabling them to have some rest.'It's my opinion
column22: ' Charlie answered
column23: 'that the reception we gave them has taken the pluck out of them
column24: and that we shan't be troubled with them for some days. Then
column25: perhaps

column27: with the result that every man on duty was instructed to keep an extra sharp look-out. The order was
column28: as a matter of fact
column29: not needed; for the sentries were as alert as they possibly could be. Hour after hour they peered into the darkness
column30: but without seeing any signs of the enemy.At daybreak Number One and his assistant cooks brought breakfast to the shivering defenders. They enjoyed their breakfast thoroughly
column31: and thanked Number One for its excellence. He smiled
column32: and sent his assistants away with the crockery. He himself remained
column33: without asking permission
column34: upon the platform. A spare rifle was there
column35: and he took possession of it. Barton was about to send him back to the kitchen when Charlie suddenly exclaimed

column57: the sooner you quit this place the more likely you will be to get away unhurt.'The packing being finished
column58: the four friends sat down to have a chat. Of course they spoke chiefly of the Boxer rising
column59: but they discussed also the latest news from the outside world
column60: and finally talked of home.'Now
column61: ' Williams said
column62: when they had chatted for about an hour
column63: 'you had better turn in
column64: for you must start as soon after daybreak as possible. I should advise you to draw some of those rugs together
column65: and sleep here. That's what I'm going to do.'
